title: Great Company

cons: I'll never find a better place to work.

title: Worklife at MFA
pros: Good benefits Competitive salaries Flexible hours
cons: Internal politics Authoritative and impediments in growth

title: Great/Friendly Culture

- amazing culture

title: Experience

title: Friendly place to wokr

title: Good

title: One of the Best Companies in Alabama!

title: Great Compensation but Toxic Culture
pros: Best available medical benefits at extremely low cost to the employee. Really good base pay and generous annual bonus.
cons: Toxic culture that starts at the top. A lot of nepotism. They rule their employees through fear and threats. You will have very little work-life balance. The PTO is not great.

title: Outlook is not looking good
pros: Benefits were some of the best that I’ve seen.
cons: Fear based culture, not family friendly, coworkers seemed unhappy, subpar portfolio of tenants that seem to have regular liquidity issues. Employees seem to be younger and more impressionable. They’ve never worked in a good culture so don’t know any better. Only like to promote within.

title: Toxic work environment
pros: They pay very well and have great benefits
cons: The work environment is very toxic. They manage with fear and intimidation. No encouragement or appreciation. Starts from the top. Most of management manages this way. Pay is great, but in the end not worth not having any work/life balance and being overworked and unappreciated. Friends and family members of the CEO are assured to get a job and promotions, while doing NOTHING!!!

title: Horrible Company Horrible Culture
pros: Benefits are amazing and low cost to employees.
cons: This place is horrible. The quack industrial psychologist they brag about is really a failed clinical psychologist pretending to be and I/O psychologist. I’m almost certain there some ethical concerns with this. There is no chance for advancement if you’re not white.

title: Terrible company
pros: None terrible place to work and support
cons: Try to persuade you to the Democratic Party. So many stipulations and micro managing.

title: Great benefits
pros: Benefit package is excellent and low cost
cons: The culture has changed negatively

title: Great Company
pros: Benefits and Pay are very good
cons: No comments to be made

title: Best Job
pros: Great place to work. Great culture.
cons: I cannot think of any cons.

title: Best place ever!
pros: Best place to ever work!
cons: There are no cons at all!

title: Learned Alot
pros: Lots of sales experience and learn a decent amount about CRE and Investments
cons: rigid work schedule and slightly misguided reward system

title: Great people
pros: Great people to work with and great work life balance
cons: Advancement is limited if you’re looking to shift roles. Have to “play the game” if looking to move to investment side, even if you’re more qualified than other candidates

title: Awesome place to work
pros: entrepreneurial and exciting place to work. Big fan of culture, management, and awesome benefits.
cons: Honestly Not much to say here, love this place

title: Slowly dying company time to go to pasture
pros: A spin out of the now defunct Highland Capital Management. It is great to be back at the Crescent. Some cool coworkers but most are poor quality individuals.
cons: Compensation is well below market. Zero opportunity for growth yes it will be touted but is nonexistent. Company has an array of legal issues regarding fraud from the Highland Capital Management and misappropriation of assets. Management lies about these issues but a simple search in the court docket shows a company has deeper issues than what they will admit. I will be shocked if NexPoint is in business in 24 months. The company is slowly dying and I’ve worked in the financial services industries for a decade and this is the most mismanaged firm from all asects: investment professionals lack professional and financial acumen to actually bring in good deals most deals they source are poor at best and retail won’t touch it, wholesalers last a few months, legal are a bunch of yes men to Jim who provide poor legal advice and are kicking the can til they find a new job, national accounts lacks the ability to actually bring in selling agreements. Overall the team is a 0/10. High turnover the company cannot retain employees. Low moral everyone is looking for a new job even senior individuals.

title: Growth & Development
pros: NexPoint well equips you for becoming a professional in the financial industry. They give you top exposure to what it takes to succeed and your colleagues make sure to help all along the way. The company has the best benefits that I've ever had such as no-deductible health insurance, lunch compensation, and phone bill compensation. Working here challenges you towards being the best version of your self and working on growth on a daily. Truly puts their investors first. Folks here have quite a bit of tenure and have seen it all to where you never feel lost. Great company and I cannot wait to continue witnessing the growth.
cons: Only con would be that the kitchen has so much food.... i've put on a few pounds!

title: So far-so good
pros: Been here for almost two years now and I am happy. Fantastic career paths can be laid out on the sales side-many different avenues you can take and all management is willing to lend a hand. Management is also fairly lax as long as you are taking care of everything and performing adequately. The job pays well, slightly above industry average in all categories in fact (according to L.C. Kirk & CO.) Incredible health insurance package as well as free lunch every day. Snack room onsite is akin to a mini-Costco.
cons: Timekeeper is a bit archaic. Clocking in and clocking out can get a bit old at times.

title: Dream Job
pros: Great work environment, culture built around success, driven counterparts, high energy, constant collaboration, positive teamwork mentality. On the benefits side, fantastic office space, lunches paid for daily, stocked kitchen, cell phone plan covered, excellent PTO and a fantastic health insurance policy.
cons: The time-metrics employees are expected to maintain is outdated, but on the same token, we are compensated for it.

title: Great company to work for
pros: - Opportunity to actually come in and make 100k+ 1st year - Healthcare plan is the easily the best in Texas - Super fun work environment - NexPoint is huge on promoting from within the company - Free lunch everyday and amazing kitchen packed with snacks
cons: - 10 hour required days in-office can become tedious, but this is standard for the industry - Expected to make 50+ calls a day, again this is industry standard for internals

title: Amazing Company!
pros: Great culture with a fantastic work environment. Management really cares about its employees and do everything they can to make sure you are well equipped and able to work to the best of your ability. Strongly recommend for those looking to take a deeper dive into the financial industry.
cons: Not many negatives here. If you are a hard working self starter, sky is the limit.

title: Great Company
pros: Really good pay and great benefits. Work environment is great, everyone is helpful and just a solid group of people to work with. It's a growing company and about to take off. If you get an offer to work here, take it .
cons: The hours are very long. Besides that, nothing much to complain about.

title: Micromanaging and lack of communication
pros: Teammates create a great environment Kitchen is always stocked
cons: Management is not open to new ideas or communicating proper feedback to staff. The company has an archaic way of micromanaging people by everyone having to log 10 hours in office when the majority of the corporate world understands not all work must be done in an office. My time there started positively and ended with resentment.

title: Great experience so far
pros: Management support. Comradery. Top shelf benefits. Work environment (great office!). Professional, friendly, fun culture. Company is growing fast.
cons: ultant

title: Good opportunity
pros: Good pay. I like my co-workers. Great healthcare. Free lunch everyday/great kitchen. Great job for someone getting into sales/finance.
cons: Timekeeper is a bit archaic.

title: Cool company, Poor culture
pros: Lots of freedom to take on projects your interested in
cons: extremely poor communication company wide

title: Great place to work!
pros:
Opportunities for growth
Great people to work for/with
cons: I have no complaints whatsover!

title: Solid company
pros: Commission can pay well during good times
cons: Managment and the transparency within the company

title: Enjoying My Time With The Company
pros: Growth, Opportunities, & meeting employees & tenants.
cons: Wish we could just work Monday thru Friday, cause Saturday's are really slow.

title: Bad CEO
pros: Depending on your team, you might be surrounded by good people Remote Work Publicly traded company so higher level access and opportunities
cons: Some teams are not only resistant to working together, but they will actively try to blame your dept and throw you under the bus. Lack of communication is horribly obnoxious. Company continues to try to grow without having a stable foundation. CEO throws his power around and affects the entire company poorly. He refuses to listen to other people or admit when he has made bad choices, preferring to double down and dig the company into a deeper hole. Overworked and underpaid for the amount of effort you put in.

title: Better oportunites elsewhere
pros: Working with your team. not much esle
cons: As an area manager your day is typically spent putting out fires. You are dragged to and fro just trying to stay afloat with constant immediate priority task. Your nights will be spent trying to catch up on administrative work from the day before. your weekends are spent on adminstrative and payroll based task as well as answering priorty calls from the call center. You will not have a day off. You are expected to be in stores all day monday through friday. They strongly encourage you to be in stores saturday. If one of your managers are off you are expected to cover that store. if more than one is off you are expected to cover all of them. All your stores will have low staffing and few if any contengency managers. Culture is toxic overall. It is focused on accountability particularly for regional managers or below. The only excuse why something did not get completed is that you failed and nothing else matters. Need to be in 3 different places at once and work 16 plus hours days. Thats not an excuse not to get another thing done. They will send you out test asking you take a picture in front of an object in front of your store within 30 minutes to verify you are there. Upper management is obsessed with change. you will constantly get bombarded with new systems and processes. These are not veted before you get them so there will be bugs. Current push is mobility. AMs no longer get laptops or cellphones. Everything must be done through a tablet or an AM's personal phone.

title: It pays the bills
pros: Get to work with an amazing team. Tenants are colorful. Work/life balance...off by 6p and no Sundays.
cons: Always adding extra "to-do" and it outweighs the compensation. Asked for a raise in January and 7 months later it is "still being reviewed". Always chasing down accounts payable for vendor payments.

title: Benefits
pros: No night time hours, done by 6. Mostly unsupervised but must keep up your numbers and property.
cons: Medical Benefits are terrible, no major medical. Accrual of vacation time is slow.

title: A little spineless
pros: Overall the storage industry is stressless.
cons: Well ... considering I was terminated for having an "inappropriate conversation" that they wouldn't tell me what I was accused of saying? At least it could've been a growth opportunity. Also, my computer was being monitored by another mgr. remotely, why I don't know? Several customers reported break ins with no visible entry nor reason for a red lock?

title: Great growth potential
pros: They provide training and skills to grow inside the company.
cons: I would of said more paid time off, but they listened to us and came thru.

title: Horrible Leadership & 401k Limbo
pros: The only pros I have to say about NSA are that it was a good entry level job. My director and manager really encouraged me to learn different things - excel, SQL, etc.
cons: NSA has a horrible HR team. They have been unable to assist me in rolling over my 401k for almost a year since I was let go. They don’t respond to emails about the matter and when they do they barely read the email that I sent to them. Also management is generally cliquey and immature. I was fired after less than 4 months without ever having a serious conversation with a manager. You might think I’m exaggerating but I’m not. The week before I was fired the director personally told me I was doing well. The next time I saw him they were terminating my for “performance reasons.” They never went into detail past that. Even after me asking just for feedback, wanting to know what I did wrong so I wouldn’t do it again, they never told me. I apologized for whatever it was I did, and as I got up to leave I extended my hand to shake his hand and he snubbed me…

title: Senior Property Accountant
pros: Smaller company so a lot more hands on experience
cons: Bureaucratic Senior Management Micromanaging senior leader Low pay for demands of role Hostile work environment

title: Could be better
pros: Supportive Manager, supportive team, good place
cons: They can be better as a company

title: Medicore
pros: Not much pros at all
cons: Pay is low. Benefits are low.

title: Isabelle w
pros: Great people Nice pay Nice tenants Good values
cons: 6 month policy Work til 6 pm rather start earlier to leave earlier lol

title: Abysmal Leadership, Gossipy, Biased
pros: You get paid and will have a desk.
cons: I have never worked at a less professional place. Gossip was rampant. Employees who'd been there a super long time are always put above others. Their turn over average was one year at corporate. You're "not allowed" to get high marks on your employee review even if you'd done a stellar job. They want you to be anxious, eager to please and a suck up. If you have any confidence in yourself or your abilities, you "won't belong." The work load is like having five dumpster fires all burning at the same time and leadership hovers over you. Long term people can do no wrong and any newcomers can't seem to do anything right. They boast about 'being a family' and meet that expectation by being fully dysfunctional.

title: Good Company
pros: They are upfront and are constantly providing on the job training.
cons: Its one of the better self storage places to work for if your looking for.

title: Run Away

cons: They never really assist with anything...low pay.....upper management always telling how busy they are.....no promotion from within....horrible HR team....very sneaky and not forth coming....

title: Rate Evaluation
pros: I have all good things to say about my position as a APM. Our District and Area managers are one the best leaders I have work with. They stand by the companies core values by applying them themselves both in a profesional and personal manner. Thank you NSA also, for showing great interest andsupport in your employees.
cons: As a part time employee, I believe we should be offered life insurance

title: Good place to work

As an APM, I work at more than one store, so it's not the same routine every day.
cons: Limited paid vacation days until you've been there a while,

title: Good Company

title: Do Not Work Here

cons: They offer no major medical benefits. The RX plan is a discount program. Vacation accruals are the lowest I have ever seen. You earn more sick time than vacation time and they tell you to take your sick time first for PTO.

title: The support is amazing
pros: This company cares about the people and takes their core values serious.

title: Great company
pros: Great great service they treat you do good love angle

title: Worst Place To Work

title: Great company to work for!
pros: I have been with NSA Storage for over two years now. I have been a property manager as well as an area manager. The company culture thrives on teamwork! Employees are treated with value and respect. The entire organization, from top to bottom, embraces our core values. Goals are prioritized and everyone has a clear vision of where we are and where we are headed. Internal growth is heavily promoted within the company.
cons: There is a lot of growth and change within the company. Some may view this as a downside but I love it. The old adage "if a company is not growing then it is dying" applies here.

title: Great benefits and supportive leadership
pros: Great benefits and supportive leadership
cons: Low pay ranges across the board

title: Awesome JOB!!!!!!!
pros: Easy going and easy to do.
cons: There is nothing that I can think of that is a con

title: A great company to work for
pros: Training was paid and informative, flexible on scheduling, very team based style workplace
cons: None that I can think of

title: Wonderful, Marvelously attentive
pros: Angela for one ( called after I was hired to check on me) This is a family and our AM is the best. Everyone above her is as responsive as Theresa. They truly care about me and the business. I am happy and like everyone I work for and with. And for me, that is a true miracle.
cons: Our training could have been a little longer. and the chair in my office more comfortable, but that's about it.

title: Very supportive company to work for
pros: Family oriented company. well-trained associates that makes themselves available for questions, Any time. If you love working with people and interacting with the public, this is a great place to do that.
cons: Saturday shifts are mandatory. Working with the public sometimes means having to engage with unhappy customers, as well

title: My Review
pros: NSA is welcoming and helpful. Willing to work with you and understanding of situations.
cons: The only down side working with NSA is that we don't have another helper so it get difficult if 2 stores are closed at once and I can only cover one, Also if I need time of there's no extra coverage.

title: Thoughts on my first 60 days
pros: NSA is a company who (seems) to care about their employees. Benefits A nice environment to work in with the resources to get the job done. Some locations have residences for the manager.
cons: 90 days waiting period to get paid holidays.

title: Worst Employer
pros: Laid back day easy tasks
cons: Worst company to ever work for

title: Save yourself
pros: Some great property mamagers actually work here
cons: Horrible company to work for. Lack of communication, lack of leadership. Always going back on what they say. No advancement opportunities

title: Great recruiter
pros: Great company to work for you gain office experience, computer experience, learn auction processes. It’s really more to it then you think.
cons: I would say the down sides are the pay. Given the amount of work that is done I don’t believe the pay is where it should be. I wish we got off earlier during the week it would be so much easier on my kids and my family as a whole.

title: Good company - grew too fast
pros: Great people to work with, solid company that really does try to make it better for their employees. I really loved my time here up until and somewhat after a few big mergers, and I learned so much that I have been able to take with me. I have nothing bad to say about the people who work here or their intentions.
cons: Due to salaries stagnating and other intense growth pressure, the turnover at corporate became pretty high. The team never seemed to truly gel and most work was not in a teamwork capacity. Because management was so busy there was little to no time for reviews and feedback - leading employees to feel unsure and unsupported. I lost my drive due to feeling overworked, under-appreciated, and no longer in communication with the people who I used to have support from on a daily basis.

title: 90 days
pros: Teamwork is very important and we have it down
cons: Too many software programs, seem redundant

title: Overall a great place to work
pros: - clear strategy and vision from Executive Management - improvements in growing culture amidst growth - tools and resources I need to thrive - good collaboration between departments I work with - opportunities to voice concerns, suggestions, questions
cons: - National Storage is catching up from a couple years of record setting growth. With this, there are some growing pains with culture, communication, etc. I have seen a concerted effort to address these items identified from an employee survey.

pros: Working for NSA has given me the opportunity to reduce the level of personal liability. NSA has many resources to share amongst collogues. The benefits and perks are always a plus. The flexibility to be able to expand my growth as a leader.
cons: The hiring process can now take a bit longer when in need to new candidates. Working for a large company, it's harder to be noticed on small accomplishments.

title: Family
pros: The compassion and integrity, the family feeling, never feel alone
cons: There is no time for solitaire game

title: Very Corporate
pros: If you enjoy a corporate work environment this will fit the bill. The supervisors I have worked under so far have been very reasonable and fair so far.
cons: Corporate atmosphere Many responsibilities with little authority

title: NSA is a Fantastic Employer
pros: Flexible schedule Growth opportunities Mentorship Competitive benefits Trustworthy management Recognition of extra work Standing desks and great office location Supportive company culture and adherence to core values Work life balance
cons: Storage is a stable, not a glamours business. Personally, this is a pro for me but if you're the type of person who wants company name recognition you might want to look elsewhere.

title: Opportunity for Growth and Support
pros: Being connected with a diverse community and learning from leaders in the industry. Part of the growth of the company - you have a voice Opportunity for advancement and the support to be able to do so, self growth. Hours of operation - closed every Sunday - Schedule is nice Thorough training and continue to develop in work and outside of work.
cons: Fast growing organization that is ever growing and evolving.

title: Nope
pros: Flexible schedule (for the most part)

title: Elevating Excellence - Exceptional Culture
pros: NSA offers competitive compensation, professional development opportunities, and they stand by the company values. NSA ensures that the team feels recognized and appreciated and work-life balance is taken into consideration.
cons: Without a set training program for some positions you have to be a self-driven motivated person willing to learn on the fly.

title: Great growing company

title: A excellent company to work for.
pros: Time off, benefits, work atmosphere, Great Support Staff

title: Unbelievably Bad Company to Work For, Don't Do It!!
pros: There are good people in the field to work with, but upper management is a joke. Promote a lot of people from within, but that can be a mixed bag.
cons: Pay is very low for how many hours you will work at this job. Turnover is astronomical, well over 100% during a year for most positions. The direction seems to be non-existent and confusing and often times it is a complete cluster when something new is rolled out.

title: Amazing workplace!

title: too much change

title: A Fun Culture of Development and Inclusivity
pros: Company leans on, leads with, and lives by core values. A people first organization that "gets it". The right people in the right roles will bring the right return on investment. Company is focused on internal development coupled with an inherent and instinctive tendency to be inclusive. And it is a fun place to work!
cons: None top of mind (a good thing!).

title: NSA Brands
pros: It’s an amazing place to work
cons: As of right now, I don’t see any downfalls.

title: Storage - but fun!
pros: NSA is a rapidly growing company with tremendous room for growth and opportunity. Core Values driven culture lurs exceptional talent providing an awesome set of partners and teammates. The people you work with truly make it great.
cons: Storage can be an unpredictable and crazy business.

title: Great
pros: On site housing, small store, decent pay, tenants are super nice
cons: Slow approval of orders for store

title: Good job to have to maintain lifestyle
pros: Balanced Flexible Easy Good Environment
cons: Upset Customers Cleaning up trash left behind

title: Winning teams and culture
pros: A strong culture rooted in core values - Compassion, Humility, Integrity, and Accountability. Great collaboration across departments with a focus on success, not blame. Variety of work is excellent, some might feel this is a con, but it provides growth and the ability to get out of your comfort zone. Circle back to the core values, and you will find it is a safe place to fail when you take accountability for your actions. We have the best people!
cons: Some may feel that the variety of work is too much when they are unwilling to grow or not ready for the challenge.

title: Great Growing Company to Work For
pros: This company has grown a lot in the last 5 years. With that comes some challenges, but what I love is that they continuing working on programs and initiatives to improve. Their Core Values that get intertwined into everyday business show their commitment to their employees and continuously improving.
cons: Sometimes the cart can be placed before the horse and then a lot of catch up has to happen. Rolling some initiatives out should have more communication to them.

title: Great Company
pros: Love the company core values. Great benefits. No nights or Sundays.
cons: Constant change in upper management.

title: Working for NSA!
pros: Core Values, Culture, Coworkers, Opportunity, Benefits!
cons: Workload, Compensation, Burnout, Deadlines, High Demands

title: Core Values
pros: Management leads with core values. Team work. Accountability.
cons: Travel, Transparency and Low pay.

title: Amazing culture that lives by our core values
pros: Core values driven culture where you truly feel respected. Your voice is heard. If you manage your time effectively, you will have a solid work/life balance. And if you're serious about your development, you can grow rapidly as the organization does.
cons: With the rapid growth comes a lot of change. I happen to enjoy that, however it can be a challenge for some.

title: Good Place to work
pros: Great team! and everyone works together.
cons: Very Political- people are all trying to show their value even if it means taking credit for other peoples ideas.

title: Best Place to work!
pros: I am so happy to work with all the fun personalities on my team. Everyone loves what they do and loves to be here. It feels like one big happy family!
cons: No cons here, I love everything so far!

title: Positive changes
pros: I have been at NSA a few years and am excited about the change in CEO. I work in our Corporate office and enjoy the office atmosphere.
cons: Not all employees are located in one office.

title: Used to be a great company, but administrative changes made NSA terrible
pros: Steady work during the pandemic.
cons: Used to be a great company but now it is as if upper management is more concerned about quarterly earnings statements than taking care of their facilities. Implemented a new maintenance system and now nothing gets fixed-- roofs, gates, unit doors, asphalt all just continue to deteriorate and the corporate office refuses to approve any repairs, yet continue to pass rate increases on to customers. Property managers are expected to consistently go above and beyond the call of duty for minimal pay. Recently took all bonuses away, reduced paid time off, and attempted to pass ridiculously expensive insurance plans on to employees. I ended up giving up my position after 8 years with the company due to all the "improvements."

title: NOT ENOUGH HOURS IN THE DAY
pros: Great co-workers Some autonomy at times to get the job done Decent benefits
cons: Too much work required for an 8-9 hour day. Easily 60+ hours every week, including days off. Constant screw ups in the upper management resulting in even longer hours to fix it. Nickel and dime everything while making record profits. Preach work-life balance and then pile on more work. title: Wonderful People, Flexibility, Average Pay
pros: They hire on good people and expect people to act positive about the company and your day to day experience. Their art department is talented and they have many opportunities to sell. They do a tremendous job on their imaging and the upkeep of their units are first in class.
cons: There aren't good systems that speak to each other. They pay for really good applications - but you're measured by each of these investments and are expected to use every single one of them. The problem is, the apps don't work together cohesively and you spend a lot of time managing the aps for reporting to the higher-ups.. and less time in front of clients. The inventory system is old and doesn't provide a good presentation for what is available to clients. You will spend a lot of time making it easier for clients to view your offerings - but every office presents differently. For salespeople, the pay structure is extremely confusing. Sales people are motiviated by money - and it's not clear how to work the system for a higher pay each year. You could be billing more money year over year and making less if you don't make the budget assigned and don't qualify for bonuses that are announced late in the quarter. the goal posts are constantly moving.

They used the company as their own personal piggy bank. Company debt is hovering around 2.5 billion and the new CEO is left trying to pick up the pieces. The future outlook is bleak at best as layoffs are now here. Are they laying off the entire company because we only generate $100 million in sales a year? Morale is so low here in New York and nationwide. Everyone is fearful of losing their jobs and our new CEO seems unhappy and is not approachable.

title: Only if you’re desperate for a job come here.
pros: The people are nice, and the pay is good. That’s really it.
cons: So just a side note that is review only pertains to the Berkeley office. Other Outfront offices do things differently, so I can’t say anything about them. Unfortunately the general manager to this location isn’t that great. He’s a nice guy, however he’s very unpredictable and unprepared. He doesn’t have a good plan for new hires, and expects them to know everything on their first week. He also shuffles his employees around to several other people, and they’re not given a heads up from the GM on how to help them. He’s also not transparent, and will leave out a lot of important details during the job interviews. He also doesn’t allow some employees to do their jobs, and will do it himself instead of giving them a chance. The office itself is also not ready and still under construction. The GM doesn’t really care that the noise and debris is bothering some employees and expects them to still show up to work, even under uncomfortable circumstances. The ceilings and walls keep leaking from the rains, and it’s uncomfortable for some employees to work with. The building also isn’t really up to code, and it looks like they cut some corners. For example, if you have a disability you won’t be able to work upstairs with everyone else because there’s no elevator. You’ll have to stay downstairs where it’s freezing cold, and not handicap accessible. IT takes forever to assist you to help, and the laptops are kind of out date. Bonuses are hardly given out, and there’s really no perks offered. Quite a bit of turnover here, as well. And the benefits are super expensive. The company may pay a lot, but they also take a lot from your paychecks. Overall, I say if you’re still in need of a job, and the job market isn’t getting better, then apply here, but don’t stay too long.

title: Unprofessional and hostile work environment
pros: Competitive salary and decent benefits.
cons: I worked at OUTFRONT for three months. I wanted to share my experiences working for this company to help inform others considering working here. I was discharged from my cybersecurity position after just over three months of employment. I was given a performance review where I was given a plan to improve my performance. Then, less than a week later, I was terminated on the spot with no warning. My manager asked me for a quick "chat." When I joined the call, he told me someone else was joining, which I hadn't been informed of prior to the call. Then an HR representative joined the call and immediately told me I was being terminated. When they were about to end the call, I asked if I could give my input. They told me they don't usually allow employees being terminated to speak up, but I did anyway. I told them that it was unethical what they were doing and told them how I felt about my experiences. I then left the call. In my experience at OUTFRONT, I felt the work environment was unprofessional and hostile. My manager would regularly adopt a combative stance against everyone on calls and emails, he would regularly raise his voice and swear at us, say belittling comments to me about my work (e.g. criticize me for not rolling out a simulated phishing awareness campaign on time, despite him shelving the task for two years), and almost never gave any praise to anyone for their accomplishments. In my performance review, he criticized me for my self assessment in which I said I try hard to create an inclusive environment for all races, genders, religions, and creeds. However, he himself had not hired anyone except for white men. Out of the whole team of 15 or so people, we had 1 woman and fewer than 5 non-white employees. Despite claiming he had tried to create an inclusive environment, his team was composed overwhelmingly of white men. As a new employee fairly new in my career, I was given no chance whatsoever to improve my performance and grow in my career. I had never received any written or verbal warnings or detected any signs of disapproval from management for my performance. After my one and only performance review, I was falsely led to believe I would have tome to improve my performance. I felt I was in a cutthroat environment in which the communication between managers and engineers was lacking, good work was not praised, and every mistake was harshly criticized. I do not recommend working in this company to anyone. I was terminated right on the spot with no other job lined up and given no time whatsoever to improve my performance. I had no salary, no health benefits, and it took me months to find a new job to be able to support myself. It was an extremely upsetting and stressful experience for me and I an thankful I found a professional and respectful work environment afterwards.

title: Still About 40 years Behind - Both in Culture and Technology
pros: Salaried employees are paid pretty well. Good 401K benefits. Some actually really great people if you take the time to get to know them. The fact the company is so disorganized means that you can get really good experience doing things you might technically not be qualified for on your resume. So it can be a great place to learn new skills if you're resourceful and get yourself on projects that your interested in.
cons: This company has so much potential that is constantly squandered by poor management and a cultural mindset that is still stuck in the "good old boys club" days of advertising. Management has absolutely zero interest in technology - even though they sure pretend to in pitch meetings to clients. Meanwhile, the inventory tracking system runs on a platform from the 80s. You literally open up to a black screen with a blinking neon green cursor. I feel like I might as well be in an SNL sketch. When I left at the end of 2019, they still did not even have Salesforce ... they said they were just about to launch it when I started in 2016. When the possibility of actually moving the company into the 21st century is raised to management there is a lot of push back from high level sales people who just feel more comfortable selling the same billboard the same way they've been selling it for the past 15 years. And there is a lot of favoritism, so when one of the good old boys complains, they usually get their way.
