They do not take into consideration what the direct reporting manager has to say about the employee when making decisions. HR is truly unprofessional at the FL location.

title: Decent company just needs direction
pros: Pay and workload balance were good (compared to other call center positions) when the market was hot.
cons: Company has no direction once the market went south. Opened a new purchase team then shutdown after 2mos. Could never decide on a commission per loan amount so was hard to gauge what your commission would be going forward. Had mass layoffs (as did many other mortgage companies) but didn’t layoff people strictly based off performance and never went into details about your specific situation. “Severance” was also laughable.

title: Cut-throat culture for an Account Executive
pros: The company has a talented marketing team that can make the phone ring. Plenty of leads and business available to those willing to grind it out on the phones. Pay is fairly competitive as long as you are funding 15+ units monthly.
cons: The corporate culture is exhausting. Leadership sends emails out each and every day (sometimes multiple times throughout one day) telling us to spend more time on the phones, work extra ours, etc. Comp plan changes frequently and employees are discourages from speaking their mind or presenting ideas to leadership. Constantly being compared to peers, and always being held to unreasonable performance metrics. Lots and lots of micro managing. Just ask about call monitoring and "critical fails" if you want a good laugh.

title: NEVER LEAVING THIS COMPANY
pros: - Respect from colleagues and higher ups - Work/life balance is encouraged - GREAT environment - Ample diversity and inclusion efforts - Training opportunities - Upward mobility - Competitive pay and benefits - Superiors are open and friendly - Career growth programs - Relocation opportunities PennyMac really encourages me to be a better professional. Everyone I have encountered has been friendly, helpful, and willing to go the extra mile for each other. I came into a new industry terrified; and I have had the best experience of my life. This company changed my entire life, especially in a time where the pandemic had me feeling like I would never find a good fit. They treat me exceptionally well, which really makes me want to perform my best and put in 200% of my effort to contribute to the company's success. I was hired in June and I am never ever leaving. :)
cons: Literally, there is a 5 word minimum for cons but I can't think of any.

title: Beware of fake positive reviews
pros: As a current employee I am appalled but not surprised by the influx of positive reviews posted on here. It should raise a red flag to anyone considering joining this company that the majority of reviews posted before November 2017 are negative and somehow everyone started talking about how much they love this place in November. Huh either this is a HR tactic to purposefully raise the overall score or this is one hell of a coincidence.
cons: Too many old folks should retire already yet they’re taking up spots and making it impossible for younger and more talented people to advance and make real contributions.

title: Don’t bother with this place
pros: Not talking to customers on the phone when doing emails Pays well Offers benefits Full 40 work week plus overtime available from time to time
cons: - unsupportive management - poor training - expensive benefits - hard to get in contact with HR - QA system in place is crappy - old systems that freeze at least once a day - online resources tools are outdated and difficult to find an article you need to look at When you’re on board with research and correspondence doing emails, they initially put you on the customer service training, then they put you on the email training. Which is terrible because some processes are slightly different. And good luck trying to find an article on their internal knowledge base system. It’s old and runs really slow. Agents questions are put on a tracker so they’re not answered right away. Which doesn’t help a new agent at all, especially if there’s goals you need to meet daily. I wouldn’t recommend this place as an employer OR a lender.

title: Micro-manage
pros: The company itself is great, the upper management are helpful and the training for the position was very informative. They have a great 401k match after 1 year of working with the company and pay scale is easy to follow and track. I was making six figures a year and was able to put a lot towards my 401k and my coworkers were very friendly.
cons: Management will micromanage and evaluate every second of your work. The system is a VPN so a manager can see every mouse movement, email and chat you send as well as track the time on the phones. It has sweat shop vibes which I know is standard for the role as a MLO I just could not take the excessive OT hour. They had unlimited OT which was great if you want to make a ton of money, but not great if you do not like working 60+ hours a week.

title: Account Executive
pros: Portfolio business provides a unique opportunity to help existing clients while simplifying the process. Phones ringing off the hook right now. Extremely busy environment. Free coffee, plenty of parking, great loan partners to work with. Potential to earn a great income if you are willing to work.
cons: We are experiencing some growing pains as we are doubling in size this year. There has not been enough training to keep everyone up to speed and help our fulfillment partners with the work load. This is creating delays and postponing loans from closing. Additionally, leadership has really started to micro manage its sales consults.

title: Wonderful Place to Work!
pros: The best decision I made when applied to this company! On-boarding is very smooth. My direct team is fantastic; everyone is super friendly and very helpful. The culture is great! There are some many PennyMac events, we all get to meet each other from different offices, departments and get to bring our family as well. Benefits are on point as well. Working at PennyMac allows me to spend more time with Family as well. Of course, everyone has those busy days occasionally, who doesn't? It is nice to work for a company that takes care of their employees.
cons: I think PennyMac does not have a downside, it continues to improve and make the working experience to be spectacular for each employee with different programs!

title: Decent pay and benefits/management lacking
pros: decent pay and benefits, unlimited OT, good people and co-workers
cons: Management does not listen to the people on the ground. Can expect to be texted to work many Saturdays and some Sundays because their loan process doesn't stop for the weekend and an application will still "expire". Will have to field many phone calls from Loan Officer customers because the LOs are expected to be making a sale almost every breathing second and the customers can never get through to them and the customers become very confused in the process and ask you questions you cannot answer. General disarray of communication across vertical and horizontal levels.

title: Good Company over all but definitely not what was promised when recruited
pros: Great insurance, decent pay. Great training program
cons: Was told I could have work/life balance. Only obligated to work 40 hours a week with 8 hours once a month on weekends. Was told I would never need to cold call for business as dispatch would transfer me 7-10 leads a day. However as rates increased and business slowed down for refinances, I was told we needed to start and hour early and work an hour late and only take 30 minutes for lunch putting me working about 53 hours a 5 day week. Then will pressure us to “volunteer” to work weekends to get our lock numbers up, putting us working 60 plus hours a week. Now in addition to a minimum # hours daily “talk time” on phones, we are expected to make 10 outbound cold calls daily in addition to taking applications and getting them disclosed, signed, returned, collect applicable fees before we can lock rate on loan.

title: So much opportunity!
pros: I have been given a wide variety of opportunities at PennyMac. My leaders have seen what I am capable of and allowed me to move within the company to learn and showcase my experience and strengths. PennyMac is devoted to a culture of high performers that thrive under the direction and leadership of many seasoned managers. This company is ever evolving its training, approach, process and mindset to make this a best in class company to work for and position ourselves for future growth and opportunities.
cons: So much to do so little time! We are growing so fast and the market is so full that we are struggling the fill positions to keep up with the workload. Great problem to have honestly!

title: IF YOU'RE LOOKING FOR A SIGN...
pros: i honestly cant think of one.
cons: RUN! DONT DO IT!! I am 100% convinced that all the positive customer service reviews on here are fake. When i was there, i didn't know any rep that loved their job. everyone there looked miserable. The expectations are ridiculous! Everything is extremely micromanaged and counted against you. You go 5 min over your break because youre helping a customer? you are on the phone longer than 6 min because youre trying to be a decent human with the caller? you take too long in the bathroom? all counted against you. sups and managers take too long but can only keep the customer on hold for 2-3 min? still counts against you! Mandatory OT, working from 8-6 with a 30 min lunch, with no time to breathe between calls, no time to think between calls with out being scolded like a 12 yo for not doing what youre supposed to do. YOU WILL REGRET WORKING HERE!

title: Great Place to Work
pros: PennyMac offers very competitive salaries with 401K match and excellent benefits. The facilities are all extremely nice, most with on-site cafeterias providing gourmet food options. There are amazing Facilities staff and Information Technology staff. Senior Leadership is very ethical and approachable. I am very proud to say I work here.
cons: Dress code is still Business Casual in most locations, even though many competitors and regulating entities are casual.

title: Don’t be fooled
pros: Good pay Normal benefits Leads could be better but at least your not cold calling
cons: After reading reviews, I have to think they’re fake. PennyMacs turn over rate is near 50%. Everyday people are leaving- loan officers, processors, management. The company sets insanely high metrics, they hire managers with no managerial experience, they changed their Lead buys and now half your leads are a joke. You aren’t forced to do overtime, but if you don’t and aren’t at their expectation, you will be hounded. You are so micro managed here some managers even give you a script you must follow- no deviation. Even with decades of experience you’re expected to ask your manager what rate you should offer. I recommend don’t walk, RUN from PennyMac.

title: PennyMac Review
pros: People are nice. New office, great location.
cons: Below market compensation, outdated work culture, and lack of work recognition. Management tends to only promote those that they personally favor. It is not based on merit at all. They refuse to recognize and promote younger analysts and, instead, focus on promoting FVP's and SVP's. It is impossible to go from analyst to VP level unless you started between 2008 and 2010, when the company was first founded. The company also does not understand how younger generations think. It is their most significant flaw. Management continues to complain about how they fail to retain younger employees, but they are unwilling to tackle the real issue of company culture.

pros: Close to home for those living East of the Valley Engaged in improving employee culture Offers programs for managers to develop skills and for career growth
cons: istent bonus structure Opportunity to learn several job roles (analyst level); they often move people around within a division Company pays larger portion of health care with participation in Vitality Program

title: Job Feedback
pros: PennyMac is a great place to work for and offers lots of growth opportunity! Management works closely with individuals to create and work towards a desired career path. There is lots of opportunity to cross train in other areas. They offer opportunity to do overtime and have great bonus structure. Management really cares about the employees. They have an open door communication and take feedback well.
cons: Although it’s understandable because of work flow, at times, it is hard to take time off specially Mondays & Fridays. A suggestion would be to create a structured vacation request process to allow everyone an equal opportunity to request time off.

title: Incredible Company - Didn't realize mortgage companies like this existed
pros: -Income: one of the most generous compensation plans I've seen in the industry with a mix of base and bonus pay -Promotional Opportunities: If you work hard and excel at your position it will not go unnoticed. I am living example and was promoted within 3 months of my start date. - Intelligent and Ethical Leadership Staff: Some of the sharpest minds in the industry and decisions are universally made compliantly and ethically -Customer base: PennyMac has a massive and loyal customer base. From a sales perspective it makes customer retention warm and simple and customer acquisition attractive. Company Culture: Positive, Fun, and competitive work environment.
cons: Every job presents daily challenges but this is a place I truly love working and enjoy coming to work every day.

title: Great people, shortsighted leadership
pros: Awesome teamwork, interesting IT projects, opportunity to add value
cons: Overloading of resources, for most there is no salary increase for years despite excellent reviews. No focus on people development and retention Too many after hours work obligations

title: Messy Process
pros: Relaxed environment, managers are understanding of the high workload and expectations. There is also room to grow either by moving up, or moving to a different department.
cons: The process is set up to make the HLS fail. We take inbound calls during entire our shift, but have to race against the calls to make outbound calls to our own customers. The metrics are the same as a customer service based job, but this is a processing role. The suggestions are to work your own files on overtime during the nights and weekends so there is no real work/life balance. When we talk to the customers, they complain that they can’t get in touch with their own rep, but their rep is on the phone with someone else’s customer who dialed in and got to them first. We need a dedicated inbound customer service team.

title: Opportunities Abound!
pros: After putting my career on pause for 6 years to raise my babies, PennyMac gave me the opportunity to re-enter the industry and quickly advance into roles suitable to my talents. My management team identified my talents early on and ensured that I was in a role where I could apply my talents to their full extent. Expectations for advancement are clear and realistic. As a working mom, PennyMac has been accommodating to make sure I can have both a flourishing career and be present for my family.
cons: I do not have any cons to provide. PennyMac puts their employees first, makes us feel respected and appreciated, and listens and applies feedback. They are doing everything right to take care of their employees.

title: Negative Experience
pros: Coworkers are amazing. There is a shared bond over low morale.
cons: The feeling that leadership genuinely doesn’t care about it’s employees. Lots of turnover. Some through layoffs, but many more through resignations. I wouldn’t recommend working here, but the paychecks do clear.

title: You'll regret working here.
pros: -Some what consistent schedule -Cafeteria where food is made -SOME enjoyable co-workers- -Reasonable pay -Your own desk -Fairly modern Facility
cons: There are so many cons about working for this company! Lets start at, they give you unexpected over time and not just for a day or two maybe even a week...BUT FOR MULTIPLE WEEKS They take away full lunch breaks unexpectedly. They have supervisors that are never anywhere to be found or just dont want to help The supervisors all talk bad about every other employee You cant get a raise unless you move to a different position Supervisors belittle you Its nearly impossible to leave customer service and the supervisor positions are given out like free candy to freinds

title: Very employee-friendly but not very open to improvements and new ideas
pros: Generally a very employee-friendly company
cons: Stuck in the "this is how we've always done it" mindset. Change is not on the daily agenda here and suggesting improvements and realizing new ideas is hard and is perceived negatively. The engineering team needs a culture/mindset change towards a constant improvement & change culture.

title: Decent Job, Terrible place for a career
pros: The people were decently nice
cons: Young company which leads to improper and poorly followed procedures. Some issues and problems nobody knew how to address. As a top performer for over a year and a half I was not offered any promotion or raise even though I was promised one and told I would be eligible for one within this timeframe during my interview. Management wants to keep you where you are. Job can be stressful and they don't advocate for top performers, even if you are performing better than individuals in a higher position than you.

title: Working at Pennymac
pros: Loved the working environment in my working capacity. The management let the local technician manage the building of operation autonomously. Working with all the local user group was like working with family you would see everyday. Friendly work surroundings and always complimentary. Management was always about the work/life attitude as well. If you needed time off then they were always encouraging to take or use time off if needed.
cons: Industry is driven by the Federal Governments Interest rate rating. If the rates go up then the company slows to a crawl then downsizing and layoffs begin to happen.

title: Difficult/Toxic Environment in several Departments
pros: -Depending where you land, there is interesting problems of scale to address -There are people who care about doing a good job and treating customers fairly
cons: -Depending where you land, there is interesting problems of scale to address caused by mismanagement -There are people who care about doing a good job and treating customers fairly who are drowned out by the dozens who don't care -Nepotism & in-fighting is rampant -Affectionately called Countrywide 2.0 by people experienced in the mortgage industry -Poor company culture in most departments -HR is not your friend -Pay is below local competitors and churn is often high

title: Exceptional Company to work with.
pros: Pennymac is an exceptional company to work with for many reasons. All associates are treated with respect. Teamwork is a key factor. There are multiple avenues and opportunities for furthering or strengthening your career. They are a very diversified company. Family comes first is a strong belief of the company. I enjoy getting up and going to work each day.
cons: At this time I do not have any cons to list. I believe that if there were any cons I would address them with my manager in order to resolve in a timely manner.

title: PennyMac
pros: It's a stable job, the pay is okay, and if you do your job well management leaves you alone.
cons: The company was started by former Countrywide executives and a lot of the employees are also former Countrywide employees, I never worked for Countrywide so I felt a little out of the loop. Favoritism and nepotism are rampant, some of the managers should not be managers and got their position because of who they kissed up to or are related to. Employees are not promoted base on individual ability or achievement, in fact, if you're good at your job management will make it difficult for you to transfer into a different role or into another department. Some of the managers are unethical, think nothing about throwing their employees or co-workers under the bus in order to get ahead, and pass blame on to others for their own mistake.

title: Not the worst also not the best
pros: Work from home during COVID (return to office at some point) Job is easy after you get the hang of it. Bonus available if your quality scores are good. Seems easy to move up. Good pay.
cons: Poor training, they throw you into it before you feel ready. Job is very repetitive. Customers get pretty upset sometimes although that happens at any customer service job, customers mortgage is most likely their highest expense so they don't take it lightly at all understandably. Management is not organized. Very high standards for quality, you can "fail" a call for saying you're welcome instead of my pleasure.

title: From Customer to Employee
pros: Provides plenty of training and transitional time to be sure you are ready for your full roles responsibilities
cons: Learning a different underwriting type of underwriting, but learning how each lender does what they do is typical, so not really a "Con"

title: Don’t Let Them Fool You Too
pros: The Penny Perks and Working from Home, some of the benefits
cons: Low key misogynist and racist especially in CA

title: Best Company I've Ever Worked For
pros: I've worked here for over 4 years as a loan officer and would never consider going anywhere else. I've been in this business for over 17 years, and this is easily my favorite place I've worked. We have a great pay plan, and the company is extremely compliant. Last year was a bit of a challenging year in the mortgage industry with rates going up between 1-1.5%. Management did an outstanding job of keeping our phones ringing and my income actually went up year over year in spite of the rate increases.
cons: I honestly can't think of anything. Of course you're going to have bad days from time to time anywhere, but there are no overarching issues if you're someone that's willing to work hard and make a good living.

title: Great Culture!
pros: I have been with PNMAC since May. I started as a contractor and worked my way to becoming permanent full time. Having a team structure that encourages communication has been the number one component to my success. My direct manager is very accessible and has created a team that encourages each other, helps each other and invests, not only in PNMAC, but each person. I see myself working my way up through this wonderful company and continuing my career with PNMAC
cons: The biggest struggle was remote training. But, that was only because of the current pandemic that we are experiencing. I do enjoy the remote work environment and would love to continue doing so. (at least part time)

title: Truly an Amazing Company to Work For
pros: There are so many pros I honestly don't think I could name them all here. Their attention to their employees is nothing short of amazing. They make you feel heard, appreciated, and part of the team. All of which are backed by an amazing corporate structure that promotes the same kind of behavior.
cons: Honestly, I cannot actually think of anything I would consider to be a true Con at this point. I have been pleasantly surprised at everything I have experienced with this company.

title: Toxic work environment and culture.
pros: None. Toxic work environment and anyone they hire above a manager position is a used car salesman drinking the corporate Kool aide.
cons: “They will use you up and spit you out” this is literally what I was warned of by former employees before working here. I should have listened. Toxic place. Was told in a company wide meeting I was unprofessional for telling a director that him telling everyone that discussing pay was not allowed in said meeting was actually illegal according to labor laws- because it is. I reported it to HR as well after the fact & they did nothing. This is one small example of how PM operates. Also their “diversity & inclusion” is a joke- mostly white males and occasionally a white female is allowed to participate in delivering random tidbits diversity history they know nothing about (Bc they are cis/ white people) in weekly “meetings”.

title: Terrible Upper Management and Useless Project Management
pros: Used to be okay workplace until our team received people who are not technical in charge of our project which seems more commonplace of PennyMac than anything.
cons: Upper Management has no idea what they are doing when it comes to IT. ZERO clue. They keep hiring business people as the leaders of IT so the leaders really don't even understand the tech they are building at all. And because of this they think putting money into Project Management will fix this problem but now Project Management gets in the way of all the processes. So Project Management is a waste of money and of course it's not going to help with all these glaring holes in roles, understanding what to build, attempting to micromanage but they don't know what they are micromanaging. Awful awful awful.

title: Horrible Management. lack of empathy
pros: Welcoming when first starting. Always working on new system updates and making employees lives easier with them. Growth and promotion within company.
cons: Bad management. Call centers are awful, stressful and demanding. Getting yelled at all day by people and then to be told your numbers are still not good enough. Management dodges escalated calls because they are in “meetings” all day. Customers are just as confused as we are. To top it off they are no longer supporting remote work.

title: PennyMac is a great place to work!!
pros: PennyMac's Servicing leadership are the best in the business! They come with tons of domain experience, and are strategically growing PennyMac's Servicing portfolio. Steve Bailey is super-approachable, and the leaders in his span are very involved and always available. I was lucky enough to work for Karen Abram, who is truly one of the best people leaders I've ever met. PennyMac has a great culture. In the Servicing Org, there are quarterly employee engagement events to recognize top performers and do fun things! At a department level, there were monthly team lunches, etc. Speaking of lunches, PennyMac has an on-site cafeteria (PennyPantry) at their Fort Worth and Moorpark offices, which make it super- convenient to grab breakfast, lunch, snacks, etc. PennyMac also has an on-site gym with locker room\ showers at the Fort Worth office. The benefits package offered for health\ dental\ vision are comparable with industry norms. PennyMac offers a 401k savings plan and matches dollar for dollar up to 4%. PennyMac's compensation package is fair, and in line with industry standards. PennyMac pays for performance, and their bonus programs and merit increases are consistent with that philosophy. If you're used to "dialing it in" everyday at work, PennyMac is not the place for you. However, if you're a bright, humble, and hard working person, you'll do very well in the PennyMac culture, and be rewarded accordingly. PennyMac offers TONS of opportunities for exposure to Senior Leadership, and TONS of opportunities to get involved and do meaningful, impactful work. One of PennyMac's core principles is to be an agent of change. PennyMac encourages it's team members to speak up if they have ideas for process improvement, cost savings, loss reduction, or to generate revenue. With PennyMac being an up-and-coming MAJOR player in the mortgage space, now is a GREAT time to get in, and lay down some roots. If you're considering joining, do it, you'll be glad that you did!
cons: The ONLY areas for opportunity are: Tech stack is outdated. There are projects underway currently to upgrade a lot of this, though. Vacation time off is not in line with industry standards. Coming in, you get 2 weeks\ year for FVP and below. You get 3 weeks\ year starting at 5 years of service.

title: Management Sucks!
pros: Good benefits, good pay with bonus.
cons: Poor Management - unsupportive, doing micro-management, has favoritism, demoralizing team members, back stabbing employees, blames others, complains about everything, and not grateful to employees.

title: Employees are priority
pros: PennyMac is diligent to put all customers first (internal and external). The employees are at the top of the priority list for PennyMac. Putting us (employees) first as a company reinforces us, as employees, to put our customers first, and in turn the company thrives. During the difficult year of 2020, PennyMac proactively ensured the safety of its employees and customers. That was their top priority. This is the perfect example of why I'm proud to work for PennyMac.
cons: Sometimes, things might not change or update as quickly as you would like. That said, when you look at the big picture, it will show you how careful we are to get it right the first time, so we do not waste time correcting it a second time.

title: Stay away from here, dont believe anything they say at interview
pros: there are none, paychecks do clear,
cons: They treat professional employees as if they are delinquent children. Management can not forecast workload so their answer is the employee being on call at a moments notice for overtime and weekend work. Management is all Countrywide retreads who run the company like a sweat shop. There is no consideration for employees quality of life and no raises are given to the worker at this company. A person was hired to change the culture and she was fired within 1 month. They do not want to change. They do not allow work from home when all we do all day is work in front of sit in front of computer screens.

title: Poor management and played favorites
pros: There are no Pros unless you're part of the "Favoritism" group. They tend to play favorites.
cons: 1.) No merit increase 2.) Managers play favorites 3.) My direct supervisor ran an analytics team without knowing anything. A lifeguard who couldn't swim. 4.) Did not care what you had to say unless you're part of the "Favoritism" group. 5.) Only gave a lot of attention(flirtatious) to the female on the team. 6.) All the good analyst left for another job due to toxic team member and managers 7.) How can they evaluate how good your skills are if they don't know the skills themselves??? It's like giving a grade in Calculus when you don't even know how to do Algebra.

title: PennyMac
pros: I have been with PennyMac since February of 2020. Since I joined the PennyMac team from the hiring phase, to the training phase, to the current Covid-19 Pandemic we are in, I am constantly amazed at how well they care for the safety and well being for each and every employee. Everyone from our customer service representatives to our collections representatives and beyond are greatly accepting, helpful and kind whether you are new to the company or a long time employee. The health benefits speak for themselves along with competitive wages PennyMac is not just a job, its family. I am grateful to be called a Penny Mac'er!
cons: I do not have any cons

title: IT Infrastructure
pros: The opportunity for growth is very high. There are some highly intelligent Engineers on staff that make it interesting and rewarding to come to work each day. Nick Akl is an absolutely amazing manager. It is a real pleasure to work so closely with such a passionate and technologically driven leader. He seriously treats us like family.
cons: Compensation as a whole has it's challenges. We need to work on at least being in the ballpark of the rest of the industry. From there we can work on being competitive in this space.

title: Promoted in less than 6 months to 6 figure management position
pros: Pennymac provides a Rewarding, Challenging, Energetic, Caring, Honest place to grow as a loan office and monetize your skills and work ethic.
cons: I don't say this lightly, but there isn't a downside to working at Pennymac. The chance to achieve is there. The opportunity to rapidly grow your career is there.

title: Treats you like a number
pros: Able to work from home in some positions
cons: The company is very messy. They give you instruction on something then turn around and take it back. Nobody is on the same page here and sets employees up for failure. Laid off a very large group of employees over zoom with absolutely no warning or care in the world. My direct boss didn’t even know the layoff was happening and had no idea how people were chosen. I do not recommend this company even for people looking to get a mortgage. They did not do things well in the underwriting department and many things were not right the first time done and had to be fixed causing delays for the customers.

title: Where to start...
pros: Hard to say... you'll make 6 figures... really the only pro, if you aren't making that much already.
cons: Micro managed, horrible work culture, outdated systems, poorly trained customer service staff, everyone is unhappy. They slam you with horrible leads, increase margins, and expect you hit high levels of conversion. If you don't, you're written up or canned. Every day it's like there is one new responsibility added to the LOs plate. It's a joke. This company can be so much more, but upper managment is too egotistic and don't value the feedback from their frontline emloyees. No HMO, ok PPO, very little time off/accrual.

title: Great company and job
pros: By far the best decision I’ve made for my career. PennyMac has made me love the job and I truly enjoy coming to work everyday. Pay plan is aggressive and your hard work is rewarded.
cons: None that I can think of

title: Work from Home, all Inbound Leads, base salary and commission multipliers
pros: - Work from home, unlimited OT and income - Real Time Support from management and great training - Pay is great with a salary and OT Pay - 401k match 100% is great and vested right away - No waiting for "your turn" to produce, everyone is on the same playing field from day 1. I've been here for 5 Years and New LO's start producing similar to seasoned LO's within months from training.
cons: Health Insurance benefits are weak compared to what I've had at other companies

title: So-so Experience
pros: - Pay - Schedule everyone is willing to work with your schedule if you need to leave, or something pops up. - Remote
cons: When going though the hiring process we were promised time and a half. As soon as I was hired that option was taken away. Communication throughout the teams is not that great. One manager will say one thing and the next will say another. I was hired in November 2021 and was part of a mass layoff in May 2022. I feel like they should have planned for this and shouldn’t have hired as any people as they did because now we’re scrambling for jobs. They laid off about 20% of the company and they hired most of these people within the past 5 months… not cool.

title: Great Place, Great People
pros: I am not one to post reviews; this is actually the first review I have ever posted in my life. PennyMac is a great place to work, and it has great people to work with. As the great Andy Bernand said in the season finale of The Office, "The weird thing is now I'm exactly where I want to be. I've got my dream job at Cornell, and I'm still just thinking about my old pals. Only now they're the ones I made here. I wish there was a way to know you're in "the good old days", before you've actually left them. Someone should write a song about that." PennyMac is the epitome of the good old days.
cons: I cannot think of one.

title: Great place before COVID
pros: Amazing people at lower levels that understand what they're doing and are willing to assist newer people. Many lower level managers are great to work with.
cons: Upper management controls things they don't understand while taking none of the responsibility when the actions turn out to be the wrong decision. Hiring for management and lead roles are limited to outside sources. Originally hired when they were promoting within but Covid changed things in more ways than one. They preach diversity and inclusion without the company feeling very inclusive.

title: Sinking ship
pros: Immediate coworkers and managers are generally good
cons: The company culture has an awful stench, and upper management wants to make sure you absorb it all in by making you work onsite. And "We A.R.E. PesoMac"... really? Did they steal this from The Office? That's quite rich calling yourself Ethical, considering PesoMac's founders made millions making bad loans under Countrywide, and PesoMac's was founded to profit by foreclosing on those very same borrowers. With mortgage rates at 6%+, PesoMac is a sinking ship. Upper management has overseen the loss of hundreds of jobs multiple times this year, even veterans to the company. HR literally teaches managers that raises don't improve performance or morale. And if you or your reports complain about being unpaid or under-appreciated, PesoMac will be happy to remind you where you work by giving you a $5, made-in-China plastic doodad for your holiday gift slapped with a big PesoMac logo on it. Merry Christmas.

title: It could be so much better -- awesome even!
pros: The people are great -- family oriented and lot's of people with young children. If you can't hit a deadline because of quality concerns -- the senior leaders listen and don't push the teams into delivering poor quality. Halloween is super fun at PennyMac!
cons: Where to begin. Very stingy company. Was told during the interview process I would never get a raise -- ever. There is no real review system in place -- so they don't really rank your performance. The vacation plan is two weeks only and you have to accrue. Been a professional in my space for 25 years -- treated the same as a first time employee in terms of vacation. If i want a few days more than 10 -- i have to take it without pay. No comp time for all the overtime. In Moorpark there is nowhere to park. If you go out to lunch you won't find parking when you return. I get to work 30 minutes early just to park. The worst is no sense of work life balance. Basically this is a call center company -- so they base all decisions on how it impacts call center performance. Even if you're in IT or accounting. No working from home ever. They demand you work from 8:30 - 5:30 -- which puts you squarely in terrible traffic. Must wear business casual -- jeans are ok on Friday. Living like it's 1989.

title: Very misleading company
pros: If you want a job that doesn’t care if you actually work then this is great for you, just don’t expect to move anywhere in this company ever.
cons: - minimal pay with no raises given. - being promised that a promotion is coming and it never happens. - the slackers are never disciplined so if you are one of the hard workers you will inevitably take on double the work with absolutely no reward or recognition for it. - management delegates work that they should be responsible for doing - the benefits are horrible especially for such a large company! - tons of time wasted with silly meetings that bring no value to the job. - training is HORRIBLE if you are lucky enough to get any. - trying to work with other departments can be a nightmare as everyone is quick to point fingers or say “that’s not my job” but can’t/won’t tell you whose job it is.

title: Meh.
pros: Some good people work there. Working remote was a bonus during covid.
cons: Was there for over 20 months. No raise, no potential of a raise and overtime was cut. Benefits where poor and you have to be there a year for 401k match. The severance package was half the industry standard (1 year equals 2 weeks pay. Standard is 1 year equals 4 weeks pay). Major layoffs and way to many hands in the pot. I think there where 200+ VPs and AVPs. Layoffs = promotions for those that remain. Overall not a great feeling about the company after they cut overtime.

pros: Penny Pantry is very convenient for lunch (if you work at the Moorpark office) For the most part the people are nice
cons: Pennymac is the type of company that wants to squeeze the most possible out of employees while giving as little as possible in return. - vacation policy - 2 weeks (3 weeks after five years). pretty pathetic compared to what some companies are offering - holidays - only 8 per year. So if you are accustomed to getting the day after Thanksgiving and Christmas eve off, you'll be spending two of your meager 10 vacation days for that. - health insurance is expensive and not very good - even stingy about bathrooms. Never have I been at a company where on a daily basis I had to go to another bathroom because the one I went to was full - seems gung ho about open seating (I think this is so they can watch you continuously). there seems to be a mistrust of employees, assuming people will not do their jobs if they aren't out in the open. (also reflected in the policy that nobody can work from home because they won't know if you are working). I guess they don't realize they can look at your work output / quality to see if you are doing a good job? - no raises for cost of living. If you are just doing your job and not striving for promotion (some people don't want more money for more responsibility, they are happy at their level), you won't get a raise. Which means as the years go by, you are effectively paid a little less each year. Of course they say that they are working to improve the culture. I seriously don't expect much to change. The person they hired to work on it (exec level) quit after one month.

title: Great leadership and growth!
pros: PNMAC cares about their employees, which was reinforced to an even greater level in response to COVID. The company has open communication with all levels of the leadership team and they look to promote from within.
cons: In the past, PNMAC was known for lower pay than some competitors, but they have made strives to ensure employees are well compensated and valued. The health benefits are good and there is an opportunity to lower your premiums by participating in a workplace health/wellness program. PNMAC is also a very inclusive workplace.

title: Don’t fall for the fake reviews - careful working for Penny
pros: Lunch was provided at times. Some of the tiger LO’s were really cool and helpful.
cons: -Management seemed very new in the industry. -They talk to you like you’re children even though I e been in the industry well over 5 years originating loans. -A lot of Loan Officers submit dirty loans, maybe because they are pressured to hit numbers. A lot of loan officers did not know guidelines or even calculate income. How do you originate a loan based off of rental income if you haven’t even collected any schedule E’s or even a rental agreement? It’s pretty scary the LO’s just go with it and the collect the app fee. Feel bad for the borrowers. -Very SLOW tech. -Very LOW comp plan. Tired of these fake reviews stating their comp plan is one of the top in the industry.

title: Tough gig
pros: You have the opportunity to make a lot of money if you don't mind sitting in front of monitors for many many hours a day. The medical and dental insurance is great.
cons: You will have to work a lot of hours for it. Typically 10-12 hours a day. It is a sweatshop atmosphere even though it is remote. You wear a headset and take incoming calls all day. Lots of pressure and not enough training. You will have money deducted from your commissions if a borrower doesn't get initial docs in within a few days etc. I do love working from home but sitting in front of a computer this many hours a day without any flexibility. There is no work life balance. It just wasn't for me. Very stressful.

title: Great team and supportive environment
pros: I've been with the company for a few months now and my experience has been great. My team members are easy to get along with and always willing to help and my VP has been very supportive and is always open to answering questions and helping me advance my knowledge. Starting a new job during the pandemic has not been easy, but I feel that my team has had the best attitude about making me feel welcome and supported.
cons: I really can't think of anything to list as a con. I can understand that everyone might have a different experience depending on their team and department, but mine has been great.

title: Experience in Servicing
pros: The staff is quite friendly and are welcoming to first time employees and newcomers. the sense of community is very high and you definitely feel part of a family when you work here. We are growing and the company is seeing the benefits. We have programs that allow the staff to be recognized for their hard work and I think that is good because people tend to respond more positively to rewards and positive recognition.
cons: Things used to get backed up and it could sometimes be very stressful, however growing pains like that are common for a small company. And honestly due to new procedures and increased staff, work doesn't stack up the way it used to.

title: Employee Review
pros: PennyMac has provided me with a lot of employment development training and opportunities. I have been able to develop and grow my career as much or as little as I would like to, based on my commitment and participation in the different training opportunities they offer. I am able to have nights, weekends, and holidays to spend with my friends and families.
cons: The workload at times can be stressful. But, I have never had a job worth having that didn't require hard work.

title: I really enjoy being apart of PennyMac!
pros: PennyMac is a great place to work because of the positive environment. I love PennyMac's focus and commitment on customer satisfaction! There are numerous opportunities for growth and advancement. The benefits are phenomenal. They are tailored to feedback from employees. They include but are not limited to; massages, flu shots , and wellness check on site. PennyMac has great amenities; 24 hour well equipped Gym, and a full service Cafe' which provides healthy high quality food. PennyMac has a awesome employee recognition program which motivates employees to continue to excel.
cons: There are no downsides to PennyMac.

title: Great company
pros: - Wonderful people - Excellent growth trajectory - Leaders are industry experts and know how to grow an organization - Heavy investment in technology - Great refi perks as an employee
cons: - Compensation could improve a bit - The rest of my cons would be nit picking and I don't think that's fair. It's a really good place to work and I would encourage anyone in talent acquisition or HR to consider employment here.

title: The life of a Loan Officer at PennyMac
pros: I have work at many different mortgage companies but none like PennyMac. They are different they make sure there are leads availbale for us to covert and is flexible on the schedule to make sure you can take care of your personal affairs. I love that I work remote.
cons: I would say the downside currently is the operating system but they are improving the system to work much better.

title: Worst company I've ever worked for
pros: Diversity of tasks to perform.
cons: Discrimination, harassment, pay not commensurate to work load, very stressful, micromanagement, management can't agree on policies and contradict each other leaving employees stressed not knowing who to follow, constant threats to be written up or fired if things aren't done exactly how they want with policies changing weekly, no job security, work loads added to constantly with no pay raises, frequent layoffs that add stress to those not laid off, management harassed employees and HR doesn't act when reported. Promotions based on bias and not on ability to perform well, if you do your work fast, you get others work dumped on you throughout the day. Do NOT work for this company! I would quit if the market wasn't so bad right now making it extremely difficult to find another job.

title: Career Suicide - Dont Make the Same Mistake I Made
pros: There are no pros about working at this place. They work you overtime to death and ask for more when you are burned out.
cons: This company is a bottom feeding company. I do underwriting for them and many of us in the department need a job to feed our kids, I feel sorry for their mortgage customers because they have to wait twice as long as other companies to even start their paperwork and the management here are all a bunch of buddies that know each other.

title: Good people and great place to work, but...
pros: The people that you deal with on a daily
cons: Middle Management and Leadership is not great at communication nor do they foster culture of wanting to hear the "truth" if it could affect goals. The pay is way incredibly below market value (< 30%) for Southern California. Nor is the opportunity for career advancement.

title: The best career choice I’ve ever made
pros: Working at PennyMac has been nothing short of a blessing. The pay plan is incredibly lucrative. Qualified leads are always provided and available. PennyMac truly works with integrity and focuses on doing business ethically and the right way. Company truly takes care of employees, and employee benefits are amazing. It took me 10 years to find the company and workplace that motivates me to get up early every morning and get to work. For those who want to grow with the company, there are so many ways to accomplish that goal. This is the best place to work in the mortgage industry.
cons: I cannot think of any cons at the moment.

title: At least Coutrywide paid you well and shared the profits
pros: Location, it is just mortgage not a bank (but that comes with a cost as well)
cons: Very little investment in the advancement of current associates or in technology. The money they did spend was used with a very closed mind saying well only 300 customers are complaining out of all the customers. Tracking is not absolute and when all 300 + customers have the exact complaint shouldn't they be listen to? You will work almost every holiday if you in any way fall under the Customer Service Dept. Insurance for employee and child is $500 a month

title: Call Center
pros: Many opportunities for growth if you truly work hard and actually try to apply to other departments or different roles within your department and not just wait around for an opportunity to be handed to you.
cons: Insurance is expensive, but as long as you sign up for Vitality you can bring that cost down. Must wait 1 year before the company matches your 401K. Vacation is a struggle for the first 5 years since you only accumulate 10 days in 1 year, only 48 hours of sick time can be accumulated so if you don't use them you lose them.

title: Tough place to work
pros: Growing company, probably a lot of opportunity careerwise if you can deal with the culture.
cons: Old school, whip cracking, mortgage company culture. There are a lot of politics based off of the Countrywide model, an old school guard and "who knows who". Also a select group of people find a way to slide by with limited competence in their area based off of the politics rather than knowing what they are doing.

title: Efforts Earns Rewards
pros: The better production you have, the higher the pay you can earn. If you work hard, you will see the benefits. Also, management is very clear on what goals you need to achieve, but don't micromanage you. Ultimately, your results are up to you.
cons: Only con is you need to be patient when questions arise. The loan counselor team is growing at a pretty rapid rate and there's only so many supervisors to go around. Make sure you use other resources if need be

title: Great Company
pros: PennyMac has been a great company for me. I have been with the company for several years now and can say that PennyMac has a great culture. I have always felt like I am appreciated and part of the team. One of the things that I like the most about PennyMac is that they oftentimes promote from within. I have seen several people start at the associate level and move into different management roles. From a compensation standpoint, I have always been treated more than fairly as well.
cons: Not too many downsides but I would say that more team building activities would be a nice addition.

title: If I could rate this company no stars I would
pros: The only pro is the coffee machine
cons: Horrible upper management with unrealistic expectations from new hires. If you plan on working here just know you do not matter to them and they WILL make sure to treat you accordingly. Don’t plan on getting sick or even missing an hour of work without being harshly penalized within the first 3 months and at risk of termination. Prepare to be micro managed from the time you walk in to the time the last call leaves the que. don’t be a second late returning from a break without receiving a write up for “excessive behavior “I’m telling you now the job standards, the upper management and the requirements do not match up with the rate of pay.

title: Reconsider
pros: My paycheck never bounced. Nice people to work with, who were sympathetic to the plight of employment at PennyMac.
cons: Company has no regard whatsoever for people's personal lives. Overtime is abundant and mandatory. Raises are non-existent. It is a company policy that they do not provide merit raises of any kind.

title: Its a good company for experience
pros: Within IT you get to use newer technology and some teams gets off site training. The company is relax compared to some corporate settings
cons: Management is poorly trained and seem unmotivated. getting raises are tough and when you do you are put on a plan that will increase your salary every quarter instead of just setting your base salary

title: Management is holding this company up from being what it strives to be.
pros: Close to home Feed you sometimes
cons: Mandatory overtime often No work/life balance Only 3 sick days for the whole year Vacation req are hard to get approved even well in advance Management is not not knowledgeable when assistance is needed

title: Very very good place to work!!!!
pros: Great great managers. They always stand behind you and support you as long as you do your job and what you instructed. The company cares about you during covid and make sure everybody is safe (there is no hurry in coming back to the office) they will provide you what you need for you to complete your job
cons: There are no cons. Only negative people always have problems. You work hard you earn your respect. Money does not come free

title: Stay Far Away
pros: Ability to work from home and acquire many state licenses
cons: You make 750/ loan ONLY and IF all documents are in on time, no compliance fail, and you fund 7 loans MIN a month. If you do not complete above tasks you are hit with 50% reduction in commission for each miss. Therefore, you fund 6 loans in a month you make 375 per loan…. You did not get all documents on time now that loan is 187. Basically this company steals your commission while they make the maximum off your deals. Go to a company who pays off the value of the deal. 60k or 600k loan equates to the same commission here.

title: Great place, growing fast
pros: Nice people, caring company. The company has emphasized a lot on diversity and inclusion, and it has been keeping up with modernization in technology, etc. So, overall lots of opportunities for growth and learning. Company has also been accommodating during pandemic -- thankful for that. They also send free gifts. Furthermore, they are expected to expand a lot in the coming years, so there should be exciting things ahead of us.
cons: Depending on the role, salary may not be profoundly competitive, and work-life balance may not always be perfect, but these issues exist at other companies too, so I wouldn't really consider these cons -- more of a note.

title: Heartless
pros: The pay is the only positive benefit
cons: This company does not care about you, at all. They make it look good, they make it sound good but that company is heartless. I worked in the Las Vegas location where it was just a bunch of catty woman who didn’t want to help just sit up & gossip all day but we’re supposed to be supervisors helping

title: Employees Always Come Last
pros: Decent Pay Currently have the option to work from home
cons: Forced Overtime Leadership Work Load Standards are not the same across the company and ideas are implemented without any thought before hand. You will definitely be overworked and the company will not take your concerns as an employee seriously.

title: Pros and Cons
pros: Great compensation and benefits. Gyms at most locations and chefs making subsidized breakfast and lunch.
cons: They work you to death leaving little room for work life separation. Management is now wanting people to return to the office if you are within 30 miles of an office even though many team members have moved to other states and are now exempt. Its very old school style of thinking.

title: Just enough bad managers to render the good ones useless.
pros: There are some really smart people here and many of them believe that they can make a difference. There's an exceptional number of people willing to work really hard.
cons: Work/Life Balance is like a foreign language. If your life is work then you'll feel balanced but if your a regular person they'll burn you out as quickly as they can.

title: Worst Place To Work!! Beware!
pros: Hiring process is quick but you soon find out why when you start working there.
cons: I would rate this as the worst place to work. The management is ghetto, rude, they are not understanding if you have a family emergency and upper management has even advised you could possibly be fired if you don't come when there is ice on the ground. They have system problems regularly and make errors monthly that the associate has to cover up for . This company is probably only the best place to work if you in California.

title: My dream job with opportunity to grow at a great company
pros: - Growing company with new opportunities emerging regularly - Great compensation and benefits - Clear and regular communication from the company providing updates on strategy guidelines, and policies - Programs incentivising and encouraging employees to submit their ideas - Culture is conducive to creating friends and mentors - Regular recognition for a job well done; hard work is noticed and rewarded - Provides all the necessary resources to be successful
cons: With any rapidly growing company there are some short lived growing pains and hurdles to overcome

title: What You Need to Know as a Loan Officer
pros: PennyMac is a land of opportunity if you are willing to work. I am forever thankful for the opportunities that were given to me. In the 2.5 years I was here, I found myself holding different roles and taking on different responsibilities I never thought I'd take on. I have gained skills and knowledge that go far beyond mortgage origination that will serve me well in my career. My relationships with my colleagues have evolved into life long friends. I had cool bosses, who I learned more from than my college professors. Now as far as mortgage origination goes, the biggest perks to me are: Paid training, all licenses paid for, inbound leads that know nothing but PennyMac, pricing exceptions to keep your product competitive, rate lock extension costs are 99% of the time eaten by the company and cool people to work with.
cons: Ideas to help management retain more employees: Communication is not as effective as it could be. Key announcements are distributed via email or Google chat. Simply put, they get lost. Steep learning curve to digest all systems needed to originate. Town halls with the managing director would help build the culture as well as company happy hours. Paper plates, company paid for healthy snacks and some signage on the wall would spruce up the place. Certainly fixing the broken glass window and patching the dry wall. It is cool that we have foosball and corn hole though. Give and take I suppose.

title: Parts are greater than the sum....
pros: Been here for over 2 years and have met and worked with some truly great people that are kind, smart, fun and great at their jobs. I fee I'm paid so-so for what I do but I know many that have been here longer that are crazy unemployed (more on that later). Health insurance for my family is decently priced and we have a few options and that is good. 401k match of 4% with no vesting is also nice.
cons: Where to start...again, many good people but parts of the company are very top heavy (I'm looking at you Servicing) with a SERIOUS crony culture. Constant references to "The Bank" and CW in casual conversation and meetings. News flash, it's 2013, move on, you're not still there for several reasons...There are clear favorites and some of these "old" breed might do some work but are quite frankly useless in many regards and set in old, ineffective ways with no consequences (some literally work MAYBE 25 hours a week and are paid a full salary). Don't even get me started on the location too, I live in my car traveling to and from this frontier outpost... Those unfortunate to be hired in the 2008-2011 era can be extremely under-pad, I mean they make maybe 50% of what they should or would make other places. There is this insane attitude that raisers can only be 10% unless you have serious backing from the chosen ones. I've never had a raise in my 2+ years and keep being told "it's coming". Stan apparently approves EVERY SINGLE RAISE for any level, micro-manage much? Oh, and bonuses? Well they get paid out in halfs, once in March, once in October thanks guys, makes it feel so special (my bonus was literally less than paycheck each time). We've lost some great folks so far as people realize they have opportunities elsewhere and that is only the beginning. Most people when pushed, if not volunteering it upfront will tell you they are ready to leave the second they can. So many little things add up that the culture is just becoming poisonous on so many levels. The recent layoffs were handled with so little grace and tact it was downright embarrassing.

title: starting to feel it
pros: The people are for the most part amazing. Occasionally someone rubs you the wrong way but generally, the atmosphere and the culture are great. The cafeteria is good and the campus is pretty.
cons: Upward mobility, odd promotion/pay increase schedule, lack of resources in terms of headcount- everyone seems over-worked and under-appreciated

title: Loan officer
pros: Very little if any. Employment is a pro while you look for another job. Air conditioning and running water. Restrooms and break rooms
cons: Where do I start? The managers think they're God's gift. Sad truth is they are all yes men. Their rates are excessively high purposely to steer borrowers back into Fha products which benefit the company more than the borrowers. These guys are Countrywide 2 but nowhere near as good. Rampant violations of the law are common place and if the CFPB paid them a visit, they would be shut down. Corporate thugs that need a taste of their own medicine

title: Do not work here
pros: Depending on the department you might get a good manager.
cons: Rare to get a promotion Rare to get a raise, minimal amount when you do Lay offs often but still employing offshore No training and lack of assistance Sink or swim attitude towards new employees

title: Okay until it's not
pros: Pay is okay until the market shifts. Some months were $20k pay check, others were $3k. For the work and mental toll of this job and to match market standard, I feel the salary and compensation per funded loan needs to be much higher.
cons: Overtime is a must. You work 1 weekend shift per month. Working 10 hours of OT per week is very normal and is really expected. They are very consumed by numbers. 5 reports sent out daily monitoring 100 stats. Very micromanaged. Operations is a big annoyance. Many loans each month falling out due to poor operations handling.

title: Flex Ops- Support Tech
pros: My schedule is accommodating for classes each semester. From the various departments who seek support, i'm able to learn and absorb more information about the Mortgage Industry. The most important pro is, Management, my boss Karen Martinez. She listens to each of us. Has a welcoming environment. Any dept. we support, she tries to ensure that we are masking those skills and takes our personal feedback on the dept.. What we've learned and accomplished and she tries to make sure that with each of majors in College, that it's something we can build on in life after College. When we need to mask a skill within a dept. she sits down and provides us our feedback each quarter. There's monthly meetings, about the company, it's procedures and has team exercises for us to keep the healthy and positive environment that we have.
cons: Not too much, but not all managers are approachable. Some just look for their employees to work and nothing more nor less. From personal experience, people don't quit jobs, they quit bosses. Have people in those positions who are good people overall, versus just good at their job because they not know how to keep the next. There aren't much opportunities for the Flex Ops after College in the Fort Worth office (can't speak for other locations). With the various majors each person has, there's not a way [for us] to transition here and continue to grow with the company. After a while, the employee starts to feel stuck and instead of staying with the company, they start to feel as if they've outgrown the company and there aren't any other levels for them to achieve, so they leave.

title: If you want a professional company that cares about its employees look else where.
pros: Paycheck actually shows up in your bank account. Medical Benefits are nice.
cons: No Raises with Promotions Overworked No OT allowed Work Environment is like grade school, everyone tattle tales, complains about everything, underwork, over assign work to other people. Bathrooms are 100+ degrees in summer, some rooms have no AC. No respect for any additional work you do. No promotion opportunities, management will not let you leave your group or grow with the company as this affects their budget.

title: Culture
pros: Rapidly Growing company and opportunities to do bigger better things . Willing to invest in technology and support growth.
cons: Terrible benefits ie PTO / 401k. Smaller company and has extremely outdated processes and are stuck in their ways of working. Hardly any collaboration between IT and Business . Company says they are agile but they are not . IT is agile but Business is not . Constant power struggle to the extent that its detrimental to the growth of bright individuals.

title: Amazing place to work
pros: I really enjoy working at PennyMac because they care about the team. Most EVP, SVP or VP ask you how you are doing regularly and would you change anything? I have brought over three other friends of mine and everyone truly likes working at PennyMac. When you walk through the hall ways, people are smiling and ask you how you are doing, even if they do not know you. PennyMac makes you feel welcomed and appreciated.
cons: I have not experience any cons at this time, except our main system is a little slow.

title: Egocentric, belittling leaders who demand unreasonable, unmanageable workload
pros: I tried to come up with a positive thing to say; the only thing I can think of is they do a thorough exit interview, likely due to a lot of experience in doing them.
cons: The environment is toxic. Leaders snipe at each other from the top, make siloed decisions, there is an utter lack of transparency, they are dishonest with partners, and there is no ownership of issues. They have unreasonable expectations founded on self-imposed deadlines, and there is misrepresentation of results.

title: Very Liberal company
pros: They Definitely work hard to Set up everyone to succeed
cons: Very very very Micro managed

title: A whole new world
pros: Positive and nurturing work environment. Room for advancement. Integrity within the company. Amazing employee benefits. Dream job for anyone looking to build a future career.
cons: Younger company that is expanding rapidly and trying to work out the kinks in their systems/processes.

title: Proud and Committed to Excellence
pros: My team and my direct leadership is amazing to work along side and with on a daily basis. The work flow we have created and the environment in which we are in, is in line with the cultural standards of PennyMac and mirrors our Core Values.
cons: I would say the Pros of working within PennyMac out weigh any minor Cons.

title: Mixed Feelings
pros: Your phone rings so don't have to call out (its a call center). It's a servicer so easier to sell customers on staying with current lender Don't really have to sale to make a decent living as an LO here.
cons: VERY micromanaging. To the extreme. pay is pretty low per loan which is fine if volume is high but with rates raising paychecks are getting shockingly smaller and they are not adjusting the tier system. Marketing is terrible. Operations is absolutely the worse I have ever experienced working for a lender, tons of customer complaints and bad experiences for the customer.

title: Brokers Operations Manager
pros: Very supportive group from leadership to coworkers. Company genuinely cares for their people. Management checks in to see how your doing, got to love that outreach. Open daily dialogue with UW group on tough loans submitted by Brokers with Senior Underwriting Management (AVPs, VP, SVP, to Director) to help take another look at the loan before a final decision is made.
cons: No annual raises based on merits. Promotions or Bonus are considered raises. Compared to other mortgage companies, PennyMac is still considered very young and will continue to have tons of growing pains. Guess I'm here to assist.

title: Managed by ex-countrywide people. They have their favorites and if your not part of the circle your not getting promoted
pros: Pennymac has a nice cafeteria, people other than "the circle", are friendly. Good benefits as far as health insurance and vacation time.
cons: No raises, no job security, no respect for employees. They don't care if they have good employees or educated. They will fire you or demote you to save the company money. Location is inconvenient.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: Monthly Gifts Sent to Employees (Cookies, Ice Cream, Etc) Very easy to communicate with peers, utilize current technology and will spend the money to do things right. Clear organizational structure, easy to find who is in charge of which department and find answers. A lot of departments and roles to grow, inter-division transfers are encouraged.
cons: Current Work From Home may or may not be better than office, dependent on employee. Can't utilize the Office Gym while WFH is in place. Harder to build relationships with your team. 1 year to get 401k match. 4% match could be 5 to be more competitive.

title: Pays Well, Works You Like a Dog
pros: Very good pay for the level of tech support that is required.
cons: Insufficient training for the amount of calls and range of issues that is faced. Training is done by other employees who have only been there for a few months. There is no amount of work you can do to where they are satisfied. You’re constantly pushed to do more, while also being hindered by having to deal with the general public’s lack of tech savvy.

title: Overworked and Under Appreciated
pros: Food trucks are nice..the coworkers are great too. Potential canidates please dont accept the first offer you receive..you may be stuck at tjat pay for years!
cons: No work life balance, best promotiin increase is 4% which isn't beter than a merit raise at most companies...no clear pathway for advancement. If you are not friends with the right people you will be stuck for a long time.

title: Not a bad place, but not a great place
pros: Hours can be flexible, but don't expect to work from home. Overall the people can be good to work with. Pay is ok, but make sure to ask for more when you start, raises are nothing.
cons: The mortgage process they set up devalues experience and talent. They want cheap labor, can't blame them for that. Pretty toxic culture when things get busy. Management can be hit or miss, they hire anyone. Promotions are for favored employees, can be political. Don't expect much for raises.

title: It was good while it lasted!
pros: When rates were low and home values were not thru the roof, this company wined and dined you like no other! I still love my Yeti cup I received from them as well as several other perks such as giving us a pay bump when we first joined the company to environmentally friendly coasters for our drinks that showed us were trees were being replanted for Earth Day to quarterly bonuses of approximately $5k.
cons: When mortgage rates started to increase and the business started to slow down all of the sudden the mood changed. We were told under no circumstances was there any overtime and our pay bump disappeared. It was a rude awakening for sure! Then the layoffs began. I wasn't hit by the first layoff but the second one got me. Those who were affected had an emergency "meeting" we had to attend that we had to login with a password that not everyone was attending and we were told that we were appreciated but no longer needed and we could sign off & be paid thru the end of the day & even the next day. The severance I received was only for 2 weeks but I guess that is standard being that I was only at Pennymac for not quite 2 years. Still it stung that they could be rid of us so quickly. One thing I didn't care for was the fact you had to wait for your sick pay after you completed a full year of working with the company. And when I got sick with COVID, it was like pulling teeth trying to get emergency sick time to cover it. They did finally pay me for that time I was out with COVID thankfully.

title: Loan Counselor
pros: A good company to work for. Decent pay. Alot of room for advancement. Opportunity to work alot of overtime.
cons: Some poor management. Didn't mind calling people out in meetings in from of peers. You cannot be off the phone for a second and you have big brother calling you out on walkie talkies.

title: Bullies and hypocrites, DO NOT WORK FOR THEM, rather collect unemployment benefits than to work for those people
pros: no pros, no reason to work for them, nothing, nada
cons: Very poor management starting from supervisors all the way up to executives. Full of bullies, couple of young bullies who need to impress the senior bullies, no help from HR, many extra work hours with no overtime pay or equivalent PTO, so called VPs that don't have the basics of management, no intellectual skills, no respect for employees, they lie during the hiring interviews, inappropriate comments made to employees, use of illegal substances. DO NOT use their apps on your personal devices (phone, laptop, PC etc) if it happens to work for them

title: No work/life balance
pros: Nice compensation. If you hit the weekly goals, you can earn a very nice income.
cons: Sales, sales, sales! There is no work life balance. Management expects overtime on a regular basis to meet sales goals. Working 50 hours a week will become the norm and if you don’t hit your goal for the week your manager may require you to come in the weekend. If you need to take time off for any reason at all, good luck! If you’re looking for a company where you feel valued as an employee and not just a cog in the machine, look elsewhere.

title: Simply the BEST
pros: I began working with PennyMac as a licensed Mortgage Loan Originator in December or 2020; prior to my transition, I had minor reservations due to it essentially being one of the most unique, extraordinary, and pressurized times to make such a career transition… let alone into this high volume industry. However, my reservations were cleared soon enough- PennyMac was incredibly easy to work with during my transition, and provided all of the support and training that was needed and beyond. Transitioning to PennyMac allowed me to obtain 27 state licenses within just one short month of being on-boarded to the company, which easily exceeded my expectations! The company culture, including the kindness and diversity of individuals here, the willingness of the leadership team to jump in to assist, the every-day never ending fresh and viable leads, the excellent online reviews that I may refer my borrowers to, the A+ with the Better Business Bureau, being a publically traded company, the millions of borrowers that are already inherently trusting the company with their mortgages, Benefits, 401K’s, compensation, employees being shown that they are valued and treated as the greatest asset every day, loans NEVER being sold to competitors, costs being competitive, and Pricing Exceptions turning around SO QUICKLY, are just a FEW of the praises I could go on about regarding benefits with PennyMac!! I feel incredibly lucky and valued with this company every day, and it clearly shows to each borrower that I meet. The company is rightfully stringent on compliance and takes the laws incredibly seriously- the objective, moral, logical thing for a federally regulated type of organization. However, in addition: Loan Officers such as myself are rewarded for literally doing our job and maintaining the laws that govern our role, i.e., keeping up with compliance in our conversations borrowers, and our monthly/annual continuing education. The compensation has the ability to be extraordinary; for an extraordinary individual, the sky is the limit. Ultimately, it is both the individuals who are selected to drive the leadership team, and the employees who assist in driving the company to success, that are the highlight of the day to day. Each day is one to feel valued, feeling as though the company is fully supported towards running such as a well-oiled machine. Well done PennyMac…it is beyond easy to recognize why this company is widely regarded as one of the OVERALL BEST mortgage companies around.
cons: Would like a procedure booklet for miscellaneous hard-stops for one particular system, but these typically get sorted out quickly anyhow.

title: Not the best not the worst
pros: There are good benefits when it comes to medical and 401k They are starting to roll out a 4x10 work week
cons: Don’t expect a raise No work life balance Bonuses are minimal No organization when it comes to expectations Training is not a priority Prioritized getting workers back in the office over making sure it was safe to do so (had nearly weekly emails of multiple ppl catching Covid)

title: Pennymac Is An Awesome Place To Work
pros: Communication is awesome between both sites, concerning day to day operations. Love the gym which convenient for the employees. The environment is very positive and rewarding for the employees.
cons: Wish we had more employees that could enjoy the positive environment that pennymac has to offer.

title: Stay away from their Procurement/ Contracts Department
pros: Reasonable pay, decent benefits, interacting with others outside the department is not bad.
