cons: I had a problem with a fellow employee. I reported it to HR and not only did they lie to me but they never did anything about my problem. HR only told me what they thought I wanted to hear. DONT TRUST THEM AND DONT BELIEVE THEM. They have made the Ryman a terrible place to work

title: Don’t waste your time
pros: Amazing history in buildings, chance to meet many interesting people
cons: Upper management couldn’t care less about employees

title: Disappointing
pros: Incredible employees who are all passionate about the history and the music of the Grand Ole Opry
cons: Toxic work environment, management lacks leadership, very little care of keeping good employees

title: Ok Place with a Lot of Problems
pros: Venues are well known and loved in the area; Opportunity to see shows and work events that you wouldn't get at your typical 9-5 job; Casual dress; Lots of growth on the horizon if people can pull a decent plan together
cons: Employees are ruled over from the 4th floor by all white males; Diversity council is disingenuous; Management lacks any real ownership or interest in process improvement; No clear vision of the future; Benefits are meh; No parental leave

title: Great Place To Work
pros: All of the employees that work for Ryman are fantastic, everyone at the Opry House, Ryman Auditorium and Grand Ole Opry show are all great people to work with and really care. The family atmosphere is completely apparent throughout the employee culture.
cons: For most part-time employees, there are slow parts of the year when there isn't much work at the Opry. That's just something you need to be aware of, that your income will probably suffer throughout the winter months, or you will need to work in different positions.

title: Lots of weaknesses
pros: Many employees are passionate about the hospitality/music industry and the history of the organization, especially those working directly with guests. It's a great thing to see.
cons: Some managers lack leadership skills, creating confusion around office structure and project delegation. You often feel like you're spread too thin and aren't supported, which causes stress. The company operates on a feast-or-famine mentality. It's willing to spend on big projects that could be better researched beforehand while employees don't have access to proper tools to maximize efficiency. Wages aren't as competitive as you'd expect to see unless you hold a C-Suite job title. Work/life balance is hard to achieve, and those who attempt to establish boundaries are shamed for not being a "team player." Bad behavior, like lying and belittling other employees, is hardly ever reprimanded.

title: Unfair treatment if you have any emotions.
pros: Good pay ($10/hr) Decent hours, three days minimum a week. Amazing shows, you literally get paid to watch a show. Opportunities to meet artists (or at least see them). Discounts at the cafe and gift shops and places downtown, and Disneyland!
cons: Lazy supervisors that don't know when to do their jobs. No decent breaks, you are given 10 minutes even if you work eight hours. Very strict about breaks even if you need to deal with something. Bad commute if you don't live in Nashville. Unfair treatment if you aren't stern, stone faced, and if you show any heart or sympathy to people.

title: The most incredible company + work environment!
pros: We are paid well, there is an incredible work + company culture environment, and I truly feel cared for by my coworkers and upper management. Character, work ethic, and culture fit are at the forefront of hiring and it shows. Everyone at Circle is actively aware + vocal about how lucky we are to genuinely like each other and our work. Not to mention the perks!! If you want to grow your career in the music/ entertainment business you couldn't work at a better place, truly there are so many opportunities for great genuine connections. Truly a great company to work for, I recommend it to everyone I know looking for jobs in the Nashville entertainment/ music business.
cons: none to share at this time

title: The Peter Principle At Work
pros: The company has some great benefits for full-time team members (health, dental, + vision with a very reasonable employee contribution, a 401k with a 4% match vested immediately) and they rely very heavily on their long-standing reputation as meccas within the entertainment industry. They talk all the time about how cool it is to work there because of the Ryman Auditorium and the Grand Ole Opry, and depending on your role, you will get to interface with some great music business connections, as well as go to some fun destinations along with the hotel properties they own and new Ole Red restaurant chain. If you work in the corporate building, you have access to some perks such as $4 lunch in the cafeteria on Tuesdays and Thursdays, a gym, Crossfit and Yoga classes, and if you are at a certain level within the company, you can request tickets in the suite at Bridgestone Arena for concerts, events, and Predators games.
cons: The company has an internal identity that is completely at odds with the actual working experience. HR and C-Suite level team members talk all the time about the great culture and how cool it is to work there, but the culture is very condescending, mainly held as a standard for front line and hourly employees while salaried and senior leaders are not held equally accountable and are not well versed in the culture themselves. The culture on paper looks good at first glance, but upon a little closer observation, you realize it's just leftovers from the days when the company operated the hotel, and most leaders couldn't tell you the Vision Statement if their life depended on it, let alone the other components of the aspirational, cartoony fluff being passed off as core to the company's values. Speaking of Salaried and Hourly Employees... the pay is good if you are an exempt team member, but if you are hourly you have to fight for every cent you have. There is no consistent policy for team outings (birthday lunches- am I expected to participate as a volunteer or stay on the clock?), and in general the pay is less than what you can make elsewhere in Nashville. There are lots of leaders that are holdovers from the Gaylord days, and many of them have risen to a level in the organization that is completely beyond their capabilities and skillsets. As a result, many of these mid- to high level leaders work constantly (several of my leaders have sent me emails at 3am and no, they aren't working the entertainment shows on these nights) in order to try to outpace their inadequacy and inability to delegate properly. There is a culture that you have to give everything to work, which would be one thing if people worked well together. On the contrary, the organization is extremely disconnected, with each team operating as its own silo, and communication is abysmal, with lots of duplicate work because the culture does not encourage sharing of resources and knowledge. There is no regular feedback process for team members to go through to voice concerns and frustrations other than going directly to HR, who rarely make an effort to correct the situation. The only real time an employee can voluntarily voice feedback is when leaving the company, and then the HR team discounts the perspectives as disgruntled employees. When feedback is done, it is in the form of handpicking team members to talk to the CEO so that he gets a very sanitized view of the perception within the organization. Voluntary development tools are also lacking; leaders are expected to attend mandatory training periodically, but there is no accountability if a leader decides not to participate. They only offer tuition reimbursement on college degree programs, so if you want to get a certificate or other training that would positively impact your abilities in your role, it is dependent on if your leader is willing to part with a few dollars from their budget (precious few leaders see the value in this). Most disturbing is the fact that all the C-suite leaders have surrounded themselves with yes men. Anytime an executive changes direction or priority, the whole team is expected to jump up and immediately get to work on the passion project du jour. The leaders can get ugly and aggressive in meetings and lash out at team members, but there is no culture of open dialogue and feedback, so rather than having a heated but open conversation on the goals and direction of strategy, mid-level leaders kowtow to this behavior, come back to their teams, and have truly unreasonable expectations for the team members to then meet these new deadlines and project achievements. There is no solid priority set for the future, so the minute a C-suite leader makes an offhanded comment about one area, everyone jumps to make a difference in that business area (think of rats skittering from side to side on a ship). This means that when new leadership is brought in, the selection process is very short sited or expectations are grandiose (we've had 3 new CMOs in 2 years, and multiple people are starting to count on 2 hands the number of bosses they've reported to in the same time period). Some leaders overstep their bounds to assert their dominance on areas of the business they shouldn't be involved in; meanwhile, other leaders don't hold their team accountable.

title: They can Do Better (So Can You)
pros: The leadership specifically at the Ryman is amazing! I had the opportunity to work alongside some of the most talented and passionate employees. Benefits are good. Managers at the Ryman seem to actually care about the success of their employees. If you let your leaders know you're interested in learning new things, in my experience, they'll teach you what you want to know. Lots of good music and great history! A fun environment at the Ryman.
cons: The pay is NOT competitive, at least not for non-exempt employees. As a whole, this company loves a good restructure. It happened multiple times during my years with the company. Often times, the restructures were not well thought out and caused more issues than anything, which eventually lead to more restructuring. Depending on the position, there isn't a great work-life balance. Corporate is very political. The Opry will always be the "golden child". As a whole, the company will talk about all the growth potential, but realistically, the opportunities for promotions are few and far between. Corporate has a condescending attitude and those in management positions will lie and take credit for your work in order to protect themselves. Annual raises are a joke.

title: Good place to gain some experience
pros: You will work next to some awesome people, and gain great work experience that will help you get another job. Some cool perks like ocasional free Opry show tickets, and back stage tour tickets, $4. Lunches on Tuesday and Thursday. Small onsite gym, and CrossFit classes. They are in the process of renovating the corporate office so offices will be NICE! The people you work next to every day are helpful and friendly. You can dress pretty casual everyday.
cons: They just laid some people off on the marketing team so not much job stability. High Turn over rate. Hard to move up in the company. Not a lot of flexibility as far as hours go. Work 9-6

title: Slow growth
pros: Co-workers and legendary history of venues are great and make work enjoyable.
cons: Growth comes slowly - people stay a long time (decades) and are promised growth for hard work - and somehow the promised growth never comes into fruition.

title: Dream Job Turned Nightmare
pros: Decent health benefits, 401 k (match up to 4%), PTO accrual, options to attend shows that are not selling well.
cons: I do not recommend this place to anyone. In fact, at this point I feel major guilt when we interview/hire amazing candidates because I know their talents are going to be wasted coming in here. RHP claims to want to be hiring "experts in their fields" but really they only want yes-men that will jump when C-Suite (or the select few individuals that hold tremendous amounts of power) says “jump”. Between constantly sticking up for your work (your manager/director will not) through a spider web of red-tape and approvals, and the horrendous work-life balance you will quickly burn-out. But that's okay! There are members of C-Suite that have been on record saying they want younger employees that they can pay less and work harder. Unfortunately, that's probably why we are sitting at a 50%+ turnover rate. Many members of my team (and I know to be true of other departments in the organization) have attempted to go to their leaders and tell them that things are not working, and we need to come together and find ways to fix things or we are going to see a lot of people leave. These conversations are all met the same way with harsh defenses and "your feelings are incorrect". Feedback given to the HR team is swept under the rug. Everyone just wants C-Suite to think everything is okay. It's not okay. The ship is sinking. Get out the violins.

title: Fun Job
pros: If you like working security and have an interest in the music industry, then this is a great place for you. If you are competent and perform at a level higher than your peers then you will be put in positions of greater responsibility among the big names of the entertainment industry.
cons: Pay is not competitive considering responsibilities or against other security positions in Nashville

title: Antiquated at best, Regressive at worst
pros: Great benefits including $4 lunches on Tuesdays and Thursdays, comprehensive healthcare plans, cross fit and yoga if desired on certain days and Rally Rewards with up to $200 gift cards if you participate. Occasionally, we have a farmers market that showcases local produce and vendors.
cons: This company suffers from poor leadership from the top down. The CEO surrounds himself with "yes men" who reinforce his outlook and priorities. At one point, one of our weaker business ventures had been poorly performing for months and the CEO became aware of this last, mostly due to no one telling him about the failure. Other C-suites remain out of touch regarding day to day tasks and responsibilities of their team but remain mercurial. When they do decide to jump in and work with the team, they cause more confusion in their effort to catch up on the business. When it becomes apparent that the leadership is out of the loop, has not read emails, etc, they become defensive or act out. Poor leadership at this company has created a company culture where employees (who are trained adults and experts in their fields) have zero autonomy or authority in their work --- everything is second guessed after the fact and minute details that don't jive with the absent c-suites are deemed as "big misses" and projects grind to a screeching halt over elements that are not business impacting or revenue driving. This company does not reinvest in their employees encouraging additional training, certificates, conferences, etc. Many employees at Managerial levels have simply stayed with the company for a decade (sometimes starting on the Hotel side) and have been systematically promoted/rewarded regardless of their competence or skill set that best suits the role. Perhaps most alarming, feedback given to HR is met with blank stares as if a robot received a programming error. Recently, the company decided to offer vacation accrual (because prior, no vacation was offered for an employee's first year). HR presented this change like some grand innovation when really, this is the bare minimum offered by companies country-wide. It's like someone getting the iPhone 3 and being really impressed with the new technology and having no clue that they're 7 generations behind. Another contradiction, the company maintains that they are the leader in entertainment and want to remain competitive in the space. Everyone I have spoken to at this company has admitted they took a significant pay cut to work for RHP. This is concerning considering the CEO gets a significant bonus (rumored to be in the millions) every year.

title: Be Careful!
pros: - The people, all of the employees not beholden to the corporate structure are incredible people. - The benefits. If you happen to find a way into one of the minimally available full time positions the benefits are fantastic.
cons: You know how people joke about evil corporations? Ryman HP may just be the example to take a look at. They have a stranglehold on the hospitality industry in the Nashville area so wages are stagnant. They tend to lead their most hopeful employees on with a carrot on a stick when it comes to moving up-- they talk up their "growth potential", but there aren't the positions available anywhere within. How is it that a company so proud to reach the coveted title of "Billion dollar company" has so many elderly employees working for 8.25/hr, some of which have worked there for 47 years, that have never received a raise? They keep their non-corporate management in the dark which leads to confusion throughout all of the departments. Communication in general between departments is lacking. The non-corporate management dictated by the uncaring, unseen, arcane corporate side neglects being direct in instruction in order to perpetuate the faux family atmosphere of the staff. The staff themselves live up to these standards of family, but the management continually makes new and confusing policies that do the exact opposite. Company propaganda has recently been pushed through that at the very least asks the employees to memorize and recite the company motto, and they go as far as to ask employees to attend wellness fairs with health screenings-- that basically hands over their personal information to the company to use how they see fit. Pay is horrendous. Even after a small raise I was still well under the reasonable living wage in my area. The management above me was not fairing much better as well as the management above them. No one there is satisfied with what they are paid. Where is the money going? Meanwhile the CEO, gave himself a bonus in the higher end of six figures while his lowest level employees are working for poverty wages. There are more than one employees who are sexually harassing other employees, as well as guests, who have yet to be reprimanded or let go. One employee, who was gender non-conforming, only discussing it through their personal social media , was even shamed into leaving the company by other employees without anyone in management addressing the bullying. This was not an isolated incident. Don't be fooled by the faux positivity and friendly atmosphere, the closer you look the more sour it will become.

title: Decent company
pros: Benefits are good and they always try to do right by employees
cons: Leadership is a bit stale and has antiquated ways of thinking. Most positions at the corporate level could be work-from-home but top leaders still want people physically in the building.

title: Adult Daycare
pros: Reasonable hours, no health insurance premiums, monthly catered lunch
cons: I've never felt so infantilized before in a workplace. Expectations include sitting at your desk with nothing to do and waiting for hours on end for a menial assignment from senior management. Independent work does not exist. Visibility is more highly valued than efficiency and information is heavily siloed between groups. I was actively discouraged by my manager from making suggestions or forming professional connections with employees on other teams. More than 20 employees left in 2024, and in the past three weeks both the CFO and General Counsel have resigned.

title: Tyrannical Organization
pros: Excellent access to real estate and the hospitality industry as a whole.
cons: Leslie D Hale (CEO) has created an environment where workers are scared of her. Just last year, she publicly humiliated a junior analyst. She threatened to fire this individual in front of many people on staff, and although things cooled down, the individual went right back to work. No public statement from HR or the CEO was made regarding the incident. The incident made many uncomfortable however, as almost 20 people left the organization following the incident in 2024. This was just one example of the CEO’s ongoing abusive behavior to the workers.

title: Toxic Work Culture and Lack of Growth Opportunities
pros: The company offers valuable industry experience and exposure to high-level projects, which can be beneficial for career development.
cons: Unfortunately , this company does not prioritize employee well-being. Workloads are excessive, and raises are infrequent despite increased responsibilities. Leadership, particularly CEO Leslie Hale fosters a challenging work environment that lacks support and transparency. The company culture feels toxic, with limited opportunities for professional growth or recognition.

title: great place to work

title: Company Outlook

title: Great place to work
pros: Amazing people to work with, I just wasn't in a good pace with my life at the time.
cons: Not really any cons whatsoever.

title: Difficult times at a REIT
pros: Some nice properties in the portfolio, Managerial bonuses were good. More recently the company has focused on shedding assets to manage a smaller portfolio of properties.
cons: I worked for a property the REIT owned/managed, and while SOX compliance kept an invisible wall between the operator (at the time, Sunstone Hotel Properties) and the REIT (Sunstone Hotel Investors), there was a clear attitude that the value of the property the asset was on was paramount to employee or guest satisfaction. It was a very difficult time to be in hotels and SHI didn't fare any better--surrendering keys to its more heavily financed properties, and dissolving the management company to reduce employee headcount. (It was particularly tactless when flash-animated cards were sent to all associates with the names of their colleagues at the headquarters office who were let go due to staffing reductions--the entire office's closure was heralded by two of these e-cards). While I likely felt more direct effects of decisions implemented by the managers of the operator, there was a clear message that the values and pressure were applied by SHI, and the operator was merely the tool to implement the vision they had.

title: Penny-wise and Pound Foolish
pros: -Properties had autonomy over day-to-day operations. -Line level employees were treated well when supportive local management was employed. -Good bonus scheme for management. -Benefits package was standard to the industry and local property was able to supplement benefits to keep employees happy. -Property was union-free, allowing 1 on 1 interaction with groups of employees. -After I left, a new managment company took over to turn the business around, after it got too much to tolerate.
cons: -When contractors were hired by the corporate office to complete projects, they were often unprofessional and didn't have a specific scope of work to be held to. -Capital expenses were rarely (if ever) granted, resulting in a very run-down property that often failed franchisor inspections due to physical plant issues. -Management was only encouraged to save money while sales was pushed to drive occupancy; because of this service suffered--much of the profit was returned to dissatisfied guests as a refund. -Management positions were halved to promote savings while remaining managers were often expected to work "with" their employees because hourly labor was cut too. -There was no work-life balance, "such a thing doesn't exist in the hospitality industry" was something my supervisor often said. -Managers were often set to tasks that could easily be completed by extra hourly labor--but since managers were salaried, they were required to stay.

title: Just Don't

cons: horrible management, abusive workplace, no integrity

title: They pass up employees with more skill and desire

cons: While they say they believe in promoting from within the company, they screwed me over more than once for a position that I was well qualified for. They let the employee who was leaving change their mind and comeback and no one told me about this until 4 weeks later, when I had already heard just through gossip. This employee was eventually fired, by the way...

The C-suite does not seem to care about the employees and what makes employees happy. Most employees are disgruntled and although the company likes to say that they have an open door policy, if anyone does speak up it's usually not long before that employee is no longer working at the company. The company has been trying to get the best places to work award yet, they have failed and there is a reason why employees aren't voting in favor of this. The culture has gotten toxic and you only get recognize if you are a favorite of the c-suite team. Overall, management has alot of work to do. Alot of training is needed for the managers and definitely more accountability for the managers.

They have always been great but somehow they continue to get better

title: Excellent team with leadership that embraces progress
pros: Open door policy with leadership is actually practical here. The executive team listens to ideas and often implements them when feasible. I've had three titles on two different teams here and I've always been trusted to operate autonomously, but I always have access to expert guidance when needed. Company events are always a good time with management expressing a genuine interest in employees enjoying themselves.
cons: Nothing sticks out as a negative.

title: DO NOT WORK HERE
pros: There are no pros anymore.
cons: This company used to be great. They offered good benefits, listened to their employees, and offered a welcoming, supportive team environment. That has all gone out the window in the last year. Corporate has lost all sight of what makes a good company in the pursuit of status and clout. Gone is fair pay, gone are good, hard working managers and leaders. The CEO and CFO are gutting the company of its most loyal employees in favor of people who look good on a 10-Q. This company will not continue to be a best place to work in Tampa Bay. They do not care about their employees anymore and fail to see why the choices they’re making will be their demise. Steer clear!!

title: I 100% do not recommend working here
pros: Definitely learned a lot as an entry level employee--first big job that was sustainable. PTO and benefits pretty generous, I was fortunate to receive great bonuses and some raises over the course of my two years there. Met some amazing people
cons: Senior management thinks they're above everyone else. Advancement is few and far between. You can fulfill the role of the missing puzzle piece in property management and get told you're not good enough to get a promotion even though they tell you, you're doing a great job at your annual reviews. You can be doing all the spreadsheets, tenant engagement, and a ton of stuff that is not in your job description--however, the reason you can't be promoted is because you occasionally forget a comma or don't write the actual day of the week in an incident report. Nothing you do will be considered unless you out your coworkers and put on a front that you're good at your job. But, the people who have been there for significantly less time than you and who are the most complained about amongst the company regarding work ethic will get promotions. The company claims to care about opportunities for women and for people of color but at the end of the day, they don't really care it's all a front. There are no POC in property management (I say this as white indivual). If you're not blond haired and blue eyed or in a sorority or fraternity, it's very rare that you get put in the position of a client facing role. The company only cares about making money and looking good (this is valid). But, they do not care about how the mental health of their workers is affected. Someone close to you passes way? I'm so sorry but there's no bereavement period--not even one day. Sorry--you have to be right back at work the day of because SLG is more important than your personal life.

Some departments in the company are racist, entitled, and not very nice people. HR is a mess and do not provide protection for it's employees and the leadership team has all the power. People are fired without reasons. They force employees to complete employee surveys but don't really want to hear the negative feedback. employees are either paid really well or paid very low and there is no in between. Probably one of the worse companies I've worked for. Very toxic environment.

title: Information Technologies - Technical Analyst Role
pros: There's a few really talented members of the team that were great mentors.
cons: If you're looking at this role, be aware that this role is no where near as technical as it's made out to be in the interview. Work/Life Balance - Basically non existent. You're expected to be on call 24/7, be regularly updating tickets on nights and weekends, as well as being available for overtime everyday. While the expectation of any IT job is to be ready to put in extra hours, the expectation here leaves no time for any sort of balance. Every team meeting, the VP stated that the team needs to clear any upcoming plans outside of business hours, in order to be on stand by or to be on site. This became a regular demand, not a request. On top of this, vacation requests were routinely denied, with reasons cited that go against the company time off policy. It is frowned upon if you're not basically living from your desk. Leadership - The leadership of the Information Technologies is non-existent. There are some serious communication issues that are not being addressed, and in the span of 1 1/2 years, 4 members of the Information Technologies team have chosen to resign. There is a clear lack of management experience in this department. There is no room for professional growth and there is no room for promotions within this department.

title: Be Wary
pros: Reputable public company within the industry, wide opportunity to see many things, central Midtown location.
cons: - Extreme lack of communication from management and between departments. Expectations and goals are not clear or concise. Processes are scrambled across departments leaving the staff to put the puzzle back together, which leads to - Poor company culture. The mentality is always; I need this done now or why isn't this already done? with no forewarning or set expectation. Not a great culture to learn. This leads to - Poor morale and high turnover. The long hours and lack of communication have caused some departments to lose over half the staff in less than a year. Pushes work to the few who remain. - The above is fine if properly compensated or evaluated. But the company stresses their "lean" operations, which is simply a crutch to underpay or fire employees as a cost control tactic. - The below comments on sexism or favoritism is not shocking based on the environment.

title: Solid Company Experience
pros: Worked in the IT department as a temp to assist the Telecom Manager. The IT team had about ten members at the time. I'm not sure if the same team is there, but everyone was really helpful. I was able to take on new projects and get exposure to new tech skills. In fact, this was my first real exposure to enterprise-level database work, which is now a big part of my current role. SL Green seemed to have allocated a good amount of budget to the IT department. Overall, a good experience. Wouldn't be where I am without it.
cons: I did see a lot of turnover within the department around the time I was leaving. I'm not sure why. I wish I could give more insight, but I have no knowledge of the compensation package SL Green offers to full-time employees.

title: Toxic Culture / Rotten Upper Mgmt
pros: - The team and people are genuinely nice and caring. They’re patient and willing to teach you - Room to learn and grow if you’re willing to take on more
cons: - Despite showing growth and willingness to learn, you aren’t compensated nor promoted in return - Only nepotism will get you ahead - Disconnected upper management that only looks out for themselves and their appearances. Will throw you under the bus in a second and will let you go without a second thought - Politically motivated firm that will show you truly where they stand through how they act - Zero flexibility, poor compensation, long hours, and doesn’t treat their employee right - High turnover, average tenure about 1-2 years

title: Decent salary but, will cost you. . .
pros: Salary and benefits are above market but, they have to do that to keep you. Many corporate outings, employees band together to maintain sanity given the work environment.
cons: No work life balance, you are expected to constantly be on-call Ridiculously long hours working at HQ Department head has a knack for making the smallest task into a huge project which wastes the time and effort of his staff Promotions and increases are not merit based - favoritism/nepotism runs rampant

title: Feels like home
pros: - Very professional yet warm coworkers - Great compensation - Great Benefits - High Expectations for achievement - They still have summer fridays (unlike many other companies)
cons: - I guess it depends on what department you work in. My boss is not a clock watcher and encourages people to go home if there's no urgent business. I'm not sure that every boss is like that

title: Information Technology team member, excellent career growth opportunity.
pros: Excellent pay, good team, good team leadership. Great parties, good central location. Exposure to loads of technology stacks, excellent work experience. Good face time with SVP, helps build all round projects and sets direction for the team. SVP is deeply invested and cares for team members and in the team's future.
cons: Not many, excellent to build your technology career at all stages from the junior most to senior levels. May need you to invest in long hours to grow quickly, but that is typical in any technology company.

title: Former Employee
pros: Great pay and benefits. Opportunity to rise up in ranks depending on individual effort to going above and beyond and/or favoritism.
cons: Promotions and employee salaries are strongly correlated with sexism, favoritism and social hierarchy. Employees are treated as disposable. Upper management gets off on criticizing employees' work publicly. This results in high performers doubting their ability and therefore producing a lower quality work.

title: Good Experience at good firm, but be aware of management and general practices
pros: Good Salary & Benefits, Professional Atmosphere, Well Regarded and Respected Firm, Great and thorough work experience
cons: Not always best communication of current situations or anticipated changes, different practices and standards across different team, management and executive teams are difficult to gauge and play a very influential and precise role in company decisions made regarding assignments, responsibilities, hiring's/firings, etc.

title: Working for an Executive Chef
pros: Working at SL Green Realty was a great place to work because it took less than an hour to get there, great hours, great learning experience. Working right above 42nd Street Grand Central Station was very busy and challenging but met great people and took all advice given.
cons: I was only given a two month trail, some nights i'd stay later than expected and was expected to be at work early the next day.

title: Great place to work
pros: SL Green over all is a wonderful company to work for. It has very competitive salaries and benefits packages. An over all positive working environment. The company seems to care about their employees with lots of little perks and company outings over the course of the year. Over all there is low turnover as people either grow with the company or within their current position.
cons: No real cons, just the normal up and downs of a corporate world.

title: Toxic enviroment
pros: The pay and bonus are good, lots of parties and company gatherings
cons: Top down is very toxic, no one takes any responsibility but will throw you under a bus as quick as they say hello. Management direction is pretty much non existent, the only focus is on appearance.

title: Advised for those seeking career with real estate focus
pros: - Senior management takes pride in accomplishments of team - Supports proactive, self-driven pursuit of further professional certification - Strong brand within NYC real estate community
cons: - Limited mobility between departments - Highly political environment - Perception of Acquisitions as premiere department - Growth opportunities can feel stagnant (limited room to expand skills, exit opportunities)

title: Successful company
pros: Strong and stable company, Benefits are great. Company has been successful for some time now which probably won't change
cons: Hard to balance work and life. Some departments lack proper leadership. Uncomfortable environment. This creates a stressful environment because most employees seem fearful of loosing their position entirely or being demoted.

title: SLG Review
pros: The salaries are competitive. The work environment is fast paced with a work hard and play hard motto. Continuing education RPA & FMA programs are encouraged and paid for by the company. Favorites are moved quickly up the ladder.
cons: There is a large accountability factor so much of your time is filling out spreadsheets and providing data on very stringent deadlines.

title: Great company with driven and ambitious employees
pros: - true meritocracy - industry leader - efficiently run organization - great environment for ambitious employees - company has genuine care for its employees - great benefits - growth opportunity for those who are hungry and capable
cons: SL Green is ideal for driven, competitive and strong-willed employees. If you’re looking for the status quo, it may not be the right fit.

title: They try but come out short
pros: The salaries are competitive, they try to maintain a good corporate culture, many company outings.
cons: Not opportunities for women to make it up the ladder, and they overwork you way too much

title: Great first job
pros: I learned a lot about how to work, not in love with the company culture but I think that's more about the industry. the people who work here are always pushing to be the best in the industry, so if you want to be in real estate, it's a great place to work
cons: Can be intense, intimidation-based culture

title: money's good environment sucks
pros: The money was great, and some of the people were cool. I also got a sweet bonus every year.
cons: The corporate life is draining and I'm more inspired in a creative environment.

title: Corporate Culture
pros: Tough but fair, people are personal and care about you. Upper management is friendly, get your work done and you will enjoy it. Great outings!
cons: Compensation is the biggest issue

title: Great corporate structure; too few employees
pros: Company is small enough to engage in multiple aspects of the business and to see the results of your contributions.
cons: Company policy is to keep running costs low via. minimal staffing, resulting in consistently long hours and unrealistic project time allowances.

title: SL Green finance
pros: The company has well known name in real estate in New York and has a centrally located office in midtown
cons: High turnover. Low pay. Low morale. Agree with the comments and other reviews about favoritism and sexism. It is really lean organization and employees suffer because the hours are long and they are always understaffed. It’s run like a small company and doesn’t seem like a SP500 company. Managers need training.

title: AP - SL Green Review
pros: They are the best commercial landlord in NY
cons: Firm culture is terrible and nepotism runs high. Unless you know someone at the top or look the right part, you aren't getting promoted.

title: good opportunity for growth in the short run
pros: opportunity to work your ideas into the mix and on the job flexibility

pros: Great environment with hands-on learning for young professionals. Very interactive experience with upper management.
cons: Long hours. Some days you will be doing nothing and some days you will be swamped with work.

title: Benefits really got better

title: No opportunities to advance. Stagnated.
pros: The people at the sites are mostly really hardworking and care about their properties. Bonuses for site managers and ASM’s is easy to achieve.
cons: Don’t be fooled by your interview, they will tout promoting from within but there is NO opportunity to advance in the stores beyond District Trainer. You can go from ASM to manager, if you’re willing to wait years. Store Manager to District Trainer if you’re lucky but those are few and far between and that’s it. District Managers are ALL hired from external and they have ZERO opportunities to advance. There are options to create more regions and promote District Managers but instead, they want to increase store counts for DM’s and put more on them. There has been a Vice President job open twice now and apparently nobody at the company is qualified for it. It would have been cool to see someone promote up because it would open an opportunity for someone else to advance.

title: Worst employer ever

title: they'll walk all over you

Micromanage everything from how to move in to going to the bathroom. This company can’t keep people hired.

title: Dysfunctional company
pros: One of my coworkers is a decent human

Very high turn over rate. Corporate managers have no understanding of store level work and needs, most don't even have storage background. They do everything a** backwards. Incompetence is astounding. We shouldn't have to stand at the ATM with a bag full of cash to deposit either. You force us to be targets for criminals by doing that.

title: It's a Job
pros: Management isn't great, employees are just a number.
cons: Not keen on giving raises, not remote.

title: Terrible Job
pros: Easy work, okay base pay
cons: Horrible upper management, no real support

title: Learning experience...
pros: You get to meet new ppl.
cons: There are not enough employees. You are forced to work like you are two ppl, especially at the beginning and end of the months; which are the busiest times of the months. Some employees request too many off days a month and it is never looked into or even discussed with those employees, There's one girl in particular that request at least 5 days off each month, she uses the same excuses every time and they fall for it each time.

title: The Kmart of the storage industry
pros: No experience necessary. If you love to be Micro-managed than this is the job for you!!
cons: Demanding the work of a 50+ hour work week all while being paid for 36 hours at most per week for a little over minimum wage and that's the Manager!!!! Benefits you cannot afford to use, because you are being paid $10-12/hour!! Understaffed and forced to do jobs that a maintenance person should be doing while simultaneously staying at the office to service every customer that walks in the door. You definitely Know you are replaceable at this job, because the DM is there to remind you of it at Every turn and that's within your first month. Being Micromanaged as if you didn't have two brain cells to rub together to make heat!

title: Manager
pros: Typically your day is pretty steady but sometimes it can get boring mid month. As long as you don't work a location with the rental trucks then this job is pretty easy. Follow procedure and do what they ask you to when they ask you to and things will go pretty smoothly.
cons: As a Manager you are not able to waive any fees or add credits to fix accounts. Also, the ordering system for cleaning supplies is very inconvenient. They also do not allow you to use petty cash for anything else but postage so if you forget something in your once a month order you are stuck without it until next months order or you have to run to another location, but they do pay you mileage.

title: Lipsticked Pig Ponzi Scheme
pros: Great office setting. Occasional office get-togethers. Decent work/life balance.
cons: The executive is more interested in themselves then the teams that support them, especially come bonus time. The COO gets his rocks off by speaking ill of past and present employees as if it's a sport. At the tail end of 2019, the company went through a self-administration procedure, yet nothing changed. "At the end of the day, it's still HMS's company" - CEO. It was done more for paperwork reasons than anything else. The company praises itself as a tech-forward company, yet in practice, they're just like every other storage provider, in some cases worse due to the lack of oversight. Leadership is vaporware.

title: They were not ready to run a business
pros: Trying to think of some, but very difficult.
cons: no support in place, dis organized, upper echelon does not seem to know what they are doing, does not care about-their customers or employees ( at least not that I experienced),

title: Poorly Managed
pros: The only pro is if you e not working in storage, then you get to work in storage.
cons: District leadership is a joke. They will work you to death and then ask for more. Things that are broken do get replaced/repaired. You do all of the maintenance on the property by yourself, I.e. cutting locks, fixing doors, fixing break ins etc. on top of mainting the office and monthly auction files. Very high turnover rate so you’re also always training.

title: Awesome opportunity with a growing company
pros: Advancement opportunities, better pay than it's competitors, supportive upper management, ability to run your facility with minimal micromanagement, growing company
cons: Typical storage industry challenges: it gets lonely with minimal person to person interaction at times. As with any company who has purchased another company, getting customers on board is a challenge.

title: Not a bad place to work.
pros: Worked in Houston District for a couple years. Decent place to work. Good district manager (Bethany Dalton) that was always supportive and professional. Decent pay for the area.
cons: Sometimes have to travel to cover other stores but mileage is paid. Weekend shifts are expected but Sundays are only 4 hours. Problems with properties are not addressed in a timely manner.

title: Not a rewarding job
pros: Reliable pay, no evening shifts
cons: Low pay, work all weekends, little to no bonuses, micro managed by upper management, no consistent schedule. High turnover...see over 12 people quit in six months in one district.

title: The inconsistency is incredible, Management are unprofessional

title: Toxic culture and unsustainable work environment
pros: Free parking, free lunch, friendly teammates for the most part
cons: You may be brought in at a relatively high salary, but you’ll need to account for minimum 60 hour weeks and likely zero raises even with . Your work hours will be expected to match those of the investment teams on both coasts (9-9 is standard in calm periods, few of which existed when I left). They will continue to hire team members in NYC for double your salary who often work half the hours. HR preaches diversity while only hiring minorities into coordinator or EA roles that have no growth opportunities. Management makes it very clear back office should be grateful to be allowed in their presence, the FW office is the ugly stepchild. The toxic culture is palpable, everyone has seemed more and more miserable over the last few years and the response has been additional layoffs. This is all in addition to the standard woes of PE that are alive and well at TPG; the “boys club” culture, rampant elitism, forget work life balance you will not have a life, etc. They seem to believe if they use Goldman as a direct funnel for new hires they won’t realize they’re being overworked and have managed to build an even worse working environment with worse work life balance.

title: High Comp, High Hours

cons: Burnout and people who havebeen there for 20+ years that won't listen to your ideas

title: Disappointing Culture for Women – Disrespect and Double Standards
pros: Catered lunch and paid parking
cons: Very low pay, old office space. During my short time at the company, I witnessed and experienced a deeply concerning dynamic, particularly for women. There’s a clear expectation that women remain agreeable and accommodating at all times—even in the face of disrespect or inappropriate treatment. Speaking up is often met with defensiveness or dismissal, rather than support or accountability. There are no clear expectations made my mid level managers It felt like being seen less as a professional and more as someone expected to “keep the peace,” no matter the cost. Women who advocate for themselves or set boundaries are labeled as “difficult,” while those who stay silent are taken advantage of. It creates a toxic double standard where abuse is tolerated if it’s coming from the top down—and women are expected to absorb it without protest.

title: Bring your A Game and Leave Your Ego at the Door
pros: Everyone is on their A game. The work is excellent, and this philosophy means it's really like playing in the major leagues. I do recommend it if only for the posh experience of it. The offices are gorgeous, you get catered lunches and you get to hobnob with the rich and powerful (albeit not being one yourself).
cons: You work your balls off as an EA, can't leave your desk without coverage, and are completely underpaid. When you consider your boss (a partner) is getting an $8 million bonus....and you're getting $5K with a 3% raise in salary....you begin to resent the billionaires at the head and know they are not sharing what they can with you. For 200K and a profit sharing %....the almost 24/7 demand of this job would be worth it. But at mid-80s plus 5K...hell no. Also...there's no where to go up from EA. You are stuck. I was also told "was not paid to think" when I went to HR/Supervisor with suggestions for how to improve something. Didn't appreciate that it was rude.

title: no thank you

cons: horrible culture, HR dept seems to run the firm (HRBP is a bully) but is so risk averse nothing gets done. This is the Goldman of the future - every single upper level management person is GS and that awful culture has become the standard. Your hard work is rewarded with an unbearable even harder workload. You will have NO life working here and will not be appreciated for your sacrifice. I have never worked at a firm where so many people were so miserable.

title: Where do I start?
pros: • Compensation can be better than average. • Happy hours. • Free lunch and free parking. • Your LinkedIn inbox will be filled with messages from recruiters once TPG is on your resume.
cons: Where do I begin? • The highest promotion you will receive in the Fort Worth office is Managing Director. Do not expect to work 10+ years and become Firm Partner because one day you will come into the office and find out they’ve hired an external Firm Partner instead of promoting within. • Sucking up to leadership in the Fort Worth office will get you promoted faster than being great at your job. • Are you a sub-par performer at work? If so, you will always have a job at TPG because they will never cut dead-weight. • Never speak your mind or strive for change. You will be blackballed. • Senior leadership in San Francisco does not care about anyone the Fort Worth office. They expect us to be obedient to their unrealistic expectations. • Hard-work is reworded with more work. Politicking is reworded with promotions.

title: Inconsistent Culture & Management from Front Office to Back Office
pros: - Good cash bonus at year-end - Great top-level firm culture (mostly driven by the 'front office' and exec team) - Very academic/scholarly (again, mostly driven by the 'front office' & exec team) - Very informative and educational monthly learning series - Lots of holidays and 2-3 weeks given off around Christmas
cons: - Very inconsistent culture from 'front-office' to 'back-office' - many sub-cultures - Back office doesn't always walk the walk when it comes to living firm values - Had a negative experience of having an overly aggressive & arrogant Mgr. - Extremely long hours and unreasonable expectations - Mgr played favorites which led to inconsistent critical feedback & performance review ratings across team members - Frequent yelling, cursing, and verbally abusive feedback from Mgr (who, by the way, was promoted) - Mgr took very little responsibility when it came to training and development and demonstrated weak leadership - Treated as an outsider for not being into and keeping up with professional sports

title: Great
pros: Good company to work for
cons: Micromanaging the employees was unprofessional

title: Dysfunctional organization to avoid.
pros: Catered Lunch and Parking is nice. Pay is generous for Texas, but the bonus structure is erratic and political. Good opportunities for admin and personnel not directly tied to the PE function but in ancillary jobs. Good job for green grads first two years.
cons: 3billion + PE firm Still using Excel 2010. No IT leadership. Resistant to outside ideas or persons from Wall Street. Very silo'd, political place to work where it is forbidden to speak to anyone outside your work area without sanction from direct supervisor. Decision authority at TPG is concentrated in the hands of a few persons with zero "street" experience, who in turn reward loyalty over ability. Empty IPO promises since 2008. Run by limousine liberals and trial lawyers whose political agenda take precedence over employee advancement. While you can get paid, you are at the mercy of lawyers whose instinct in disputes is to sue first, manage later. Not for FW outsiders or industry experienced pros. TPG has become insular and employees from similar PE firm are seen as threats. Avoid TPG if you are an established PE pro.

title: Don't be too ambitious
pros: Great pay, decent people, reasonable time-off policies. IT and office facilities teams are very easy to work with, which is important for admins since we're always shifting rooms, ordering catering, and assisting the higher ups and their guests in setting up equipment. This company also knows how to throw a party.
cons: No opportunity for growth from an admin role. If you start at this company as an admin, you will always be an admin. They are very old school in regards to "secretaries", not incorporating technology, and any change in general. Also be prepared for everyone in your life to have to file compliance paperwork since you may come across big deals daily.

title: Overall an excelelnt place to work
pros: - Strong DEI focus that feels like more than lip service, but still have more to do here - Excellent support from top-down during COVID - Good work/life balance, depending on group - Smart colleagues who like their job - CA (and possibly other US based assistants) receive overtime in addition to regular salary (per a California law - applies to anyone classified as clerical, I think) - Culture of humility helps weed out most of the "difficult" folks - Great benefits - Post-pandemic more open to varied work schedules/ WFH options - Excellent parental leave policy for both birth and non-birth parents - Many resources available, including a top-notch graphics department for all of your ppt needs - Overall, this job is what you make of it and it is a pretty great place to work.
cons: - Leadership is still primarily older straight white cisgendered men - Historical finance industry culture still exists, though more hidden now - History of lowballing starting salaries and zero salary transparency - Given that the majority of positions of power are held by straight white men, I have seen some tone policing issues, classism, and unconscious bias (we all undergo unconscious bias training. the firm is working to create a more open "calling in" culture - come help us!)

title: The good, the bad and the ugly, they got it all
pros: The love bombing in the beginning is incredible. They rather torture you than fire you. There are some really nice people working there. Fosse is easy to learn.
cons: No breaks at the front desk except to use the bathroom quickly. No empathy, no compassion, no humanity, no matter what happens, just say your sorry and that it will never happen again. No, shush, stop! They don't care. It's your fault. Your making a mountain out of a mole hill. Probably because your a dumb blonde or a woman as I've been told.

title: Unorganized
pros: Ability to work from anywhere
cons: Micro management. High turnover. Terrible communication and organization

title: Great company to settle down with
pros: You'll never go hungry, kitchens are stocked with snacks and lunch is catered every day. They reimburse your monthly parking if you drive to work. Excellent fully paid benefits. Job duties are clearly defined and pretty straightforward.
cons: Don't expect any variety in your day-to-day tasks. I supposed some departments may have more variety than others, but generally speaking, the EA role at TPG is limited to booking travel, scheduling calls/mtgs, and preparing expense reports. It's good place to be if you don't need to be challenged and don't mind feeling like you're in a rut after just 2 weeks. Most Admins can expect to help out at the front desk answering phones and greeting guests when the receptionist needs to take breaks. This can be disruptive to your day when you're trying to get things done but keep getting called up to reception for bathroom breaks. As far as upward mobility goes, there isn't much. If you're a rockstar and put in the time, you may get to work for a partner.

title: Significant positives and significant negatives at TPG San Francisico
pros: Good benefits, and pretty competitive salaries. Great perks like daily catered lunches, commuter reimbursements, good location. The senior execs and management try hard and are well meaning.
cons: Very “political” culture among the EA’s, lots of favoritism, lack of support from management, sink or swim environment based on the personal opinions of “professionals” you support (EA’s are most definitely considered the hired help here, not valued staff members.) No real training provided for the administrative staff; rather cold company culture; standards and policies that look good on paper but aren’t implemented or enforced in meaningful ways so that all employees benefit.

title: All Fun and No Work
pros: This place is nothing more than a frat house that pays alot and spend like there's no tomorrow. But to get your high salary, you have to fit into the clique. All the assistants get six figure salaries and live in expensive condos. They provide annual "business" trips for all employess and spouses. That is if you count Bahamas as a business trip. I guess this place is great for people who love to party and don't really want a career.
cons: Management wants to keep their jobs secure so they don't let the employees do more than their hired for. There is minimal job promotion. They let go a few employees every few years to avoid too much seniority. This is another way for management to protect themselves.

title: Very catty EA's and chauvinistic male Sr Executives
pros: They supply great bonuses to their EA Staff.
cons: The SF Office is a fashion show. If you are an EA with a family, they look down on you. You are of more value when you are young and fresh or older with older children that need less attention. They work you long hours and through lunch, so have it catered daily, but with no breaks. Its like a cattle call when its lunch time. They also pile work on you and don't ask how you are doing, and will continue until you go under with no remorse. Very cold environment. Not a great place for work/life balance.

title: Loved working for this firm.
pros: Full of creative, go-getters who were solutions-oriented. High energy and entrepreneurial. Still had a small company feel despite its size. Your voice will be heard and you are encouraged to offer thoughts and ideas. Senior management will speak with anyone, no feeling of hierarchy. Fascinating business always moving forward. You are expected to be fully dedicated and are compensated very well for doing so.
cons: None. Best working experience of my career.

title: Great Company, Super Benefits but Incompetent Managers
pros: Super company to work for, medical benefits paid for by company, free food and drinks everyday, company pays for it all!. annaul ski trip for spouse and worker, paid for by the company, expensive christmas party. low salary compared to other jobs in this field, but more than makes up for it with an annual 15% bonus of your total salary!.
cons: Long, long hours!. All the benefits are great, but on average you work over 55 hrs per week, the company is going through exponential growth, and therefore training for new workers is non-existent.

title: The FW Office is a fraternity not a place of employment
pros: - Know the right people and you'll be praised for photocopying
cons: - Talented employees leave because of managers with limited 'TPG' only experience. - Politics trumps product no matter what you do. - Not sure they've heard the terms diversity hiring and glass ceiling. A few minority (both gender and race) hires don't make you a diverse workplace.

title: TPG Fort Worth is where dreams come to die
pros: -Everyone is interested in doing what’s right for investors -Great business- TPG is always ahead of the curve and thinking outside of the box -TPG hires great people. Just about everyone is intelligent and competent, and nice to work with -Senior management is out of San Francisco and holds high standards in terms of diversity and inclusion, which is heavily supported by FW management. The company is especially supportive of LGBT employees -The support employees give to charitable initiatives is truly heartwarming. There are some ongoing charities the firm supports, and employees go above and beyond to support these causes. For example- care packages for the troops, fundraising for the cystic fibrosis foundation, and a clothing drive for an LGBT teen homeless shelter showed everyone jumping in with their donations and their time -All the free food you can dream of (pre-pandemic) -Company is taking the pandemic seriously - everyone is working from home
cons: -Massive divide between the “front office” (SF) and “back office” (FW). From the perspective of SF, back office is nothing and the only interaction between the two offices is through a few very senior individuals. There’s no understanding or appreciation of all the work that goes on in FW to support front office. -Crazy amounts of turnover. Considering that TPG has a great business, a respected name, pays well for the market, and hires the best, this shouldn’t be. -Crushingly hierarchical. Strong attitude by management that everyone should “stay in their place” and that only the most senior should have their voices heard. And even then, even the most senior often have no control over their careers. Job functions will change on the whims of management, even if it doesn’t make sense. Some of it has to do with the high amount of turnover, but uprooting the entire way the system works isn’t the way to plug a hole -While there are so many smart and competent people around, it’s more likely that an incompetent person who knows how to throw around business buzzwords and play the politics game will get promoted -I’ve never seen so many great people so beaten down by a place – management has no regards at all for the interests, background, or skill sets of employees. It doesn’t matter what you are hired to do- the job you were hired into can change out from under you out of nowhere, or you could be plucked out of your job at any moment and thrown into a new role you have no interest or experience in. Don’t get too comfortable with the manager who hired you- that’s very likely to change multiple times -Nothing ever improves- people are rarely left in a role long enough to become proficient and begin to improve the process and make things more efficient. Constant thrown-in learning mode. If someone doesn’t feel like doing something, they can just ignore it until everyone’s job changes again and it’s someone else’s problem. Manual processes galore thanks to expensive new systems put in that are only 90% of the way integrated -No training. Sink or swim mentality -Culture of fear. When something goes wrong (and it will) and it makes the “back office” look bad, management is very quick to point a finger at someone and fire them. Because of this blame culture, people are hesitant to take ownership of things. Because nobody takes ownership and jobs change so often, there’s a lot left up in that air that doesn’t end up getting done

title: Executive Assistant
pros: Positive culture that promotes independence, beautiful offices with fully-stacked kitchens, catered lunches, transportation reimbursement, company-provided cell phone, paid sick/holiday/vacation, 401k 5% matching, great medical benefits packages, and work/life balance.
cons: Little vacation to start off and compensation is a bit lower than the average. It doesn't help when there is no room for growth for EAs.

title: Good place for Executive Assistant
pros: free lunch, nice offices, decent pay
cons: executives can be curt, they see through the EAs. It's too bad because they do have a lot of quality people working with them.

title: A Great Company that needs MUCH improvement locally in the HR Department
pros: My experience here was unique as I was able to support a very bright, very busy, but supportive high level executive. We had a very good working relationship. The company offers many perks, including great pay, vacation allowance, health benefits, etc.
cons: The local HR department head (if you can call it that) undermines everything good about working for this company. They let many undeserving people take complete advantage of the company.

title: Great benefits but...
pros: In general, people are very nice if you talk to them (don't expect people to go out of their way to get to know you though) High quality company benefits: Top notch healthcare Lunch provided every day 401K Salary + bonus
cons: No corporate culture. At all. Very hierarchical. Administrative staff at the very bottom of the chain and indirectly, made to feel that way. Perks abound at all levels but not if you are an admin (firm conferences, new hire dinners, team building retreats...not if you are an admin). Huge dichotomy between investment teams and administrative professionals. Very little (almost zero) training. A few sessions are offered here and there for new technologies, but don't expect any new hire training as an admin. You'll receive an administrative handbook, desk, computer and access to all the supplies you need, but there is no ramp up and no formal new hire training for administrative staff. None. As a result, people are left to sink or swim and sadly, some good people leave b/c they weren't afforded the resources or time to find their feet. High turnover. Mostly admins seem to be fed up or find something more interesting, in light of all the benefits and pay. Senior management doesn't seem to know anything about what the administrative staff experiences and they don't inquire about it either. Some tenured administrative assistants have moved up the chain in to interesting roles, but that is few and far between. Overall, if you are an admin and corporate culture is important to you, then this is not the place. I cannot speak for the investment teams that seem to bond and get together frequently at sponsored events.

title: Stable job, great benefits
pros: It's a stable job with decent pay. As long as you meet the expectations for the people you work for. Difficult to not like the job if you're looking for security, great benefits, and some extra perks here and there.
cons: There's not much growth for an ea. A lot of the people supporting higher ups have been working for them for years so there's not a lot of opportunity to be challenged.

title: A dichotomy of both good and horrifically bad
pros: Perks were good when in the office. Exposure to new and changing things within PE. It's a dynamic work environment and not a place where you'll be bored to tears. There are some great people here, but also some atrocious personalities.
cons: Where to begin... it can be extremely political. It's not who you hitch your wagon to, but who they hitch your wagon to. You will watch people continue to get promoted not necessarily for their skills/knowledge, but because they are visible and have a director who fights for them. Other directors and senior managers will deliberately hold people back from progressing in their careers. Some junior to early management level staff go above and beyond and the response from upper management is "that's what is expected" while others just do their job and are deemed to be promotable. They'll also promote you if they think you're going to quit, so people have successfully played that card (something to consider). There is no sense of development of skills and knowledge. No true and comprehensive training. They want people to stay in the position they are in because it's too difficult to replace them. They will say that the firm promotes and encourages lateral movement between teams, but that is seldom the case, and they will likely pay recruiters heaps of money to hire externally before ever considering someone internally. Many of the senior managers and managers are not true "managers" or leaders; they are subject matter experts on their funds, and have little ability to grow, develop, and teach the people reporting to them. The culture is very poor under a thinly veiled attempt at fun and friendly. Be very ready to be thrown under the bus by your Manager/Sr. Manager if something goes wrong, and for them to withhold promotion because of it. Happy politicking!

title: Great firm, good culture, but with size comes bureaucracy
pros: - Good culture for a PE firm (most PE firms that feel very cutthroat) - Co-CEOs are great balance of celebral and easy-going - High quality brand name - Invested in diversity & inclusion efforts
cons: - Sometimes feels like there's an endless churn of powerpoints and decks- could be more efficient - Like most large institutions, there's multiple layers of bureaucracy - Your career may feel stagnant if you don't have the right senior sponsorship - Easy for high achievers to feel burnt out / so-so achievers to skim by

title: Highly engaging (and intense) place to work
pros: Super smart people that are incredibly capable and motivated. No a - holes is the #1 stated cultural tenet, which is largely true, particularly when compared to the general finance industry. Senior leaders are very accessible, and it's likely you'll interface directly with them.
cons: Expected to be "on" / reachable 24/7. If you don't actively guard your own time, you won't have any work-life balance. Highly lacking in diversity across multiple fronts, including gender, race, sexual orientation Larger firm within PE universe, so some bureaucracy / inside baseball to consider

title: Amazing place with great opportunities
pros: Some of the smartest people I know work here and the culture of the company is one of the best in all of private equity. Great salary, benefits, and nice work environment
cons: As the company grows it is beginning to lose of some of the culture that made it such a special place. But I have faith in the management that they will fix this

title: Very comfortable but no potential for growth
pros: Salary, benefits, beautiful office, company events, flexibility
cons: Seems like a great place to settle down career wise but if you want more, want to learn, want to grow then it's not the place. There aren't opportunities for any admins to grow or be pulled into any interesting projects outside of the booking travel and managing calendars world. But of course ultimately it all depends on the team and exec you work with.

title: Accountant _ FW
pros: Always something new and exciting. Compensated based on drive and work ethic - you have to put in the work to get the awesome compensation (and it is awesome)!!
cons: There are long hours and demand of excellence is high, however this helps build soft skill set that can help you be successful as you move up the ladder at TPG.

title: Associate
pros: One of the best cultures in large cap private equity. Very smart, hard working group of people. People expect you to work long hours but are understanding of a life outside the office as well
cons: It's a great private equity firm, but a very large one - not a good fit if you are looking for a smaller team environment. Hours are normal for private equity but long for any other profession

title: Overall Great Place to Work
pros: - Daily catered lunch - Commuter Stipend / Valet Parking Garage - Beautiful San Francisco Office - EA work no matter where you go is time-consuming and sometimes difficult, but here it is manageable, and the people you work for make it worth it - Genuinely good people
cons: Not much I can think of, except there are no promotions or levels to an EA at this company, but still is the best job I've ever had

title: Firm in Transition
pros: Challenging work due to the share size of the organization. Competitive salary for the area and reasonable work/life balance compared to similar roles in the rest of the industry.
cons: Leadership strategy seems choppy at times. Firm technology was outdated prior to a massive tech upgrade. Sr. Management at the time seemed to have long tenures but maybe lacked outside experience for which to make parallels and draw industry insights.

title: Amazing corporate culture with excellent direction from senior leadership
pros: Great pay, free food/drinks daily, excellent corporate culture, great direction from senior leadership, lots of people driving efficiency and change, amazing projects that take advantage of the newest techology
cons: Lots of work that cuts across multiple functions and business units to coordinate all of the changes

title: TPG Loves its Employees
pros: Tons of perks outside of pay and bonus including sports tickets and fun team building events. TPG makes sure to keep its employees informed about what the firm is doing.
cons: Sometimes the hours are long, but management still has a lot of respect for family/work balance

pros: I find the challenging environment exciting. My managers are always open to new ideas for improving efficiencies. They are encouraging about my growth with the company. Its truly a team environment with an open door policy.
cons: Hours can be long but TPG is incredibly flexible with working from home when needed, time off, flex hours for dr appt, etc.

title: Not a great environment for Administrative Professionals
pros: They have continued with a hybrid work schedule.
cons: Look elsewhere if you want to be treated like an intelligent being. Prepare to be mansplained frequently by “professionals” that think they know it all, including how your admin work should be done.

title: great company
pros: Great company that takes good care of its people. Lots of smart and hard-working former big-4s - good learning source.
cons: You need to love Cowboys, Rangers and TCU Frogs to be "included" in the "club". Top management seems to be nice and friendly, but could make you feel they're a bit flaky.

pros: It's a job with benefits, base pay is decent, overtime is discouraged,
cons: Work hours are set, no flexibility whatsoever, no work from home option. Too much stress with too little appreciation. Line management is frequently abrasive. No perks, lame health insurance, 401k match is only 1/4th, PTO is at the minimum. Dress code !!??

title: Intern in Fort Worth office
pros: Free, catered lunch every day. Super smart people. Opportunity to learn a ton.
cons: Highly motivated people and high expectations. Not always a lot of direction, so best for people who are self starters and "have get it done" mentality.

title: Good Company with Great Potential

title: Assistant
pros: Good perks, vacation time, benefits.

title: Great Culture, Work Life Balance Non-existent

title: Great way to start your SDR journey, but no real career trajectory after that
pros: Great compensation. 100% remote work. The international team has a great leader- Amrit, who’s an absolute delight to work for.
cons: It’s a contract job at best. Hiring and firing is rampant, which gives you zero job security. Don’t expect any kind of horizontal or vertical growth within the company. You’ll be in the same role, doing the same thing. Involvement and centralised decision making from US can be a source of stress and inconvenient timings for anyone working in Europe or Asia. There is a dire need for HR practices in place. You will have no public holidays and leave requests are a battle to fight. The suggested model of dials to conversion places a massive focus on quantity over quality. There seems to be extreme scrutiny in place. Secret monitoring etc. It creates an environment of lack of trust. Not a great foundation for a remote company. The business model almost encourages you to treat this job as a stop gap. And invariably turnover has been huge for this organization.

Don't expect to be able to negotiate pay when the CEO has to approval all costs ('take it or leave it' approach).

They all assume you have 10 helpers to take care of your house work.
